articles/project-notes/30-Days-of-Linux-.title: 30 Days of Linux A Complete Guide For Beginners 1f2635c581e0801eb157eb49d86440f3
articles/project-notes/30-Days-of-Linux-.content:
30 Days of Linux : A Complete Guide For Beginners
Ever thought of learning the Linux Operating System? Why do software and network engineers love Linux? why Linux is different from others. Well, why don‚Äôt you find yourself? In the next 30 days, you will learn Linux OS from scratch. Let‚Äôs get started.
In the world of operating systems, Linux stands out as a powerful, versatile, and open-source solution that has revolutionized how we interact with computers. Linux is a strong platform to build, develop, and innovate‚Äînot only for an established IT professional but also for a beginner. It‚Äôs a 30-day walk-through journey, understanding Linux step by step, from basic standard system commands to advanced system administration.
Table of Content

What is an Operating System?
What is Linux?
Why Linux?
Phase 1: Lay the Foundations (Days 1-12)

Days 1-3: Introduction to Linux
Days 4-6: Basic Linux Commands
Days 7-9: Understanding the Linux File System
Days 10-12: Basic System Operations


Phase 2: Intermediate Linux Skills (Days 13-24)

Days 13-15: Shell Scripting Basics
Days 16-18: Package Management
Days 19-21: Networking Basics
Days 22-24: Working with Text Files


Phase 3: Advanced Linux Skills (Days 25-30)

Days 25-27: System Security
Days 28-30: Performance Monitoring and Web Server Setup


Bonus Resources
Advantages of Linux
Use Cases of Linux
Conclusion

What is an Operating System?
The OS is software specifically designed to operate, control, and coordinate all the hardware and software resources available in the computer. It possesses a user interface for the management of tasks that can be done by end users‚Äîsuch as running applications, file management, and input/output management. The operating system, for example, is Windows, macOS, and Linux. The OS provides the foundation for ensuring that other programs, and especially different users, can effectively share the resources of a computer.
What is Linux?
Linux¬†is a Unix-based, open-source operating system. Created by Linus Torvalds in 1991, Linux has grown to be a major force in the tech world: powering anything from smartphones and servers to supercomputers, including embedded systems. An open-source operating system is one whose source code is made available for viewing, modification, and distribution by anybody, hence, by implication, a collaborative and innovative community.
Why Linux?

Open Source: Free to use and modify, promoting collaboration and innovations in the community.
Security: Known for its robust security features and resistance to malware and viruses.
Flexibility: It can be used for anything from a desktop to servers and also embedded systems.
Performance: Efficient resource management, suitable for both high-performance computing and low-spec devices.
Community Support: A very large, active community offering a lot of support and resources in terms of documentation and tools.

Over the next 30 days, you will delve into various aspects of Linux, starting from basic concepts to advanced topics, ensuring a solid foundation and practical skills.
Phase 1: Lay the Foundations (Days 1-12)
In the first phase of our 30-day Linux journey, we will set the base by understanding the fundamentals of Linux. You‚Äôll be introduced to what Linux is, its history, and the different distributions available. By the end of this phase, you will feel comfortable navigating the Linux environment, executing basic commands, and understanding the Linux file system.
Days 1-3: Introduction to Linux

What is Linux?
History of Linux
Linux distributions (distros)
Installing a Linux distribution (Ubuntu/Debian)

Days 4-6: Basic Linux Commands

Navigating the file system (ls,¬†cd,¬†pwd)
Managing files and directories (cp,¬†mv,¬†rm,¬†mkdir,¬†rmdir)
Viewing file content (cat,¬†more,¬†less,¬†head,¬†tail)
Basic text editing with¬†nano¬†or¬†vim

Days 7-9: Understanding the Linux File System

File system hierarchy
Understanding file and directory permissions
Using¬†chmod,¬†chown, and¬†chgrp
Symbolic links vs. hard links

Days 10-12: Basic System Operations

Managing users and groups
File and directory compression¬†(tar,¬†gzip,¬†bzip2)
Process management¬†(ps,¬†top,¬†kill)
Scheduling tasks with¬†cron

Resources:

Linux Basics Tutorial
Command Line Crash Course

Phase 2: Intermediate Linux Skills (Days 13-24)
In this phase, we‚Äôll dive into intermediate Linux skills that are essential for day-to-day operations and system management. You will learn the basics of shell scripting to automate tasks, manage software packages, and understand fundamental networking concepts. By the end of this phase, you‚Äôll be well-equipped to handle more complex tasks in a Linux environment.
Days 13-15: Shell Scripting Basics

Introduction to shell scripting
Writing simple bash scripts
Variables, loops, and conditionals in scripts

Days 16-18: Package Management

Installing and managing software with¬†apt-get¬†and¬†yum
Using¬†dpkg¬†and¬†rpm
Understanding package dependencies

Days 19-21: Networking Basics

Understanding IP addresses and subnetting
Basic networking commands (ping,¬†ifconfig,¬†netstat)
Configuring network interfaces

Days 22-24: Working with Text Files

Using¬†grep,¬†sed, and¬†awk
Searching for text patterns
Text processing and manipulation

Resources:

Shell Scripting Tutorial
Package Management Guide
Networking Basics for Linux

Phase 3: Advanced Linux Skills (Days 25-30)
In the final phase, we will explore advanced Linux skills that are crucial for system administrators and advanced users. You‚Äôll learn how to secure your Linux system, monitor its performance, and set up a web server. This phase will prepare you for real-world applications and give you the confidence to manage and troubleshoot Linux systems effectively.
Days 25-27: System Security

Securing your Linux system
Setting up a firewall with¬†iptables¬†or¬†ufw
Using¬†ssh¬†for secure remote access

Days 28-30: Performance Monitoring and Web Server Setup

Monitoring system performance (top,¬†htop,¬†vmstat)
Setting up and configuring a web server (Apache or Nginx)
Basic web server management and troubleshooting


If you wish to learn more about servers, cloud computing and devops and related thing you can checkout our course for the same.

Bonus Resources

Online tutorials and documentation for specific distributions.
Linux communities and forums for help and support.
Books and online for in-depth learning.

Advantages of Linux

Cost-effective: No costs for software licenses, which lower the overall cost of software.
Stability and Reliability: Rarely requires rebooting and can easily last for years of continuous use.
Compatibility: The hardware and software of this device support extensive compatibilities for all different environments.
Privacy: Not collecting personal data provides greater privacy to the user.
Friendly to Developers: With support for a large set of programming languages and technologies, provides the most powerful development tools and environments.

Use Cases of Linux

Servers: It rules over the server market because of its stability, security, and scalability.
Development: Developers like it because of its strong tools, possibilities for scripting, and the fact that it is open source.
Embedded Systems: This system powers devices like routers, smart TVs, and Internet of Things devices because of the lightweight and customizable nature of the operating system.
Cloud Computing: It has wide applicability in cloud environments due to its flexibility and efficiency, widely used particularly in AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud.
Education: Widely used in institutions of learning for the teaching of computer science and programming.30 Days of Linux Plan

Conclusion
By the end of this 30-day journey, you will have a solid understanding of Linux and its capabilities. You‚Äôll be equipped with the knowledge and skills to leverage Linux for various applications, from personal use to professional development and system administration. Welcome to the world of Linux, where endless possibilities await!

articles/project-notes/Cloud-Engineering.filePath: articles/project-notes/Cloud Engineering Roadmap Tech With Soleyman 1f2635c581e080c0bca0f97a89351de5.md
articles/project-notes/Cloud-Engineering.title: Cloud Engineering Roadmap Tech With Soleyman 1f2635c581e080c0bca0f97a89351de5
articles/project-notes/Cloud-Engineering.content:
Cloud Engineering Roadmap| Tech With Soleyman
Summary
I. Master IT Fundamentals
This is the bedrock upon which your cloud career will be built.  A strong grasp of these fundamentals is crucial.

Operating Systems:

Linux: Become proficient in Linux. It‚Äôs the dominant OS in cloud environments. Focus on command-line navigation, file system management, and user/permission management. Distributions like Ubuntu or CentOS are good starting points. 30 Days of Linux : A Complete Guide For Beginners
Windows: While less prevalent in the cloud, Windows still holds a significant presence. Understand its core functionalities and how it differs from Linux.
Pitfalls: Ignoring the command line, neglecting user and permission management.
Tips: Set up a virtual machine (using VirtualBox or VMware) to practice Linux commands and explore different distributions.


Scripting:

Learn a scripting language like Bash (for Linux) or PowerShell (for Windows). Automation is key in the cloud.
Pitfalls: Not practicing scripting enough to become comfortable with it.
Tips: Automate everyday tasks on your computer using scripts to gain practical experience.


Networking:

Understand the fundamentals of how computers communicate, including the OSI model, TCP/IP, and common protocols (HTTP, DNS).
IP Addressing: Master the concepts of IPv4 and IPv6 addressing, subnetting, and routing.
Pitfalls: Getting bogged down in complex networking theory without practical application.
Tips: Use online tools and visualisations to understand network concepts. Set up a simple home network to experiment with IP addressing and routing.


Security:

Learn about common security threats and vulnerabilities in IT systems.
Firewalls: Understand how firewalls work and how to configure them.
VPNs: Learn about VPNs and their role in secure communication.
Pitfalls: Underestimating the importance of security in the cloud.
Tips: Explore online resources and courses dedicated to cybersecurity fundamentals.


Programming:

Python: Python is widely used in cloud automation and scripting. Learn the basics of Python syntax, data structures, and working with libraries.
Pitfalls: Trying to become a Python expert before moving on to cloud-specific learning.
Tips: Focus on practical Python skills relevant to cloud tasks, such as working with APIs and automating infrastructure.


Databases:

SQL: Learn the basics of relational databases and SQL for querying and managing structured data.
NoSQL: Understand the concepts of NoSQL databases and their use cases for unstructured and semi-structured data.
Pitfalls: Trying to master advanced database administration before understanding basic cloud concepts.
Tips: Use online platforms like Mode Analytics or free database instances to practice SQL queries. Explore popular NoSQL databases like MongoDB.


Virtualisation:

Understand the concept of virtual machines (VMs) and how they allow multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.
Pitfalls: Confusing virtualisation with containerisation.
Tips: Set up virtual machines using VirtualBox or VMware to get hands-on experience.


Containerisation:

Learn about containers (e.g., Docker) and how they package applications and their dependencies into isolated units.
Pitfalls: Not understanding the benefits and limitations of containers compared to VMs.
Tips: Experiment with Docker by containerising a simple application and deploying it locally.



II. Pick a Cloud Platform
While the underlying concepts are similar, each cloud provider has its own set of services and tools. It‚Äôs best to focus on one platform initially.

AWS (Amazon Web Services):

Pros: Largest market share, extensive free tier for experimentation, skills highly transferable.
Cons: Can be overwhelming due to the sheer number of services, pricing can become complex.


Azure (Microsoft Azure):

Pros: Strong integration with Microsoft products and services, good for organisations already using Microsoft technologies.
Cons: Less mature than AWS in some areas, can be more expensive for certain services.


Google Cloud Platform (GCP):

Pros: Known for innovation in areas like AI/ML and big data, competitive pricing.
Cons: Smaller market share compared to AWS and Azure, some services less mature.


Pitfalls: Spreading yourself too thin by trying to learn all platforms at once.
Tips: Choose the platform that aligns with your career goals and interests. Leverage the free tier to explore and experiment.

III. Master Cloud Concepts (Focusing on AWS as an Example)

Understand the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù before the ‚Äúhow‚Äù: Don‚Äôt just learn how to use a service; understand the underlying problem it solves and its place within the cloud ecosystem.
Core Services:

EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud): The foundation for running virtual servers in the cloud. Learn about instance types, operating systems, storage options, and security.
S3 (Simple Storage Service): Object storage for various data types (images, videos, documents, etc.). Understand storage classes, access management, and data lifecycle policies.
IAM (Identity and Access Management): Crucial for controlling access to your cloud resources. Learn about users, groups, roles, and policies.
VPC (Virtual Private Cloud): Allows you to create isolated networks within AWS. Understand subnets, route tables, and security groups.
Bedrock (Generative AI service): Explore the possibilities of AI in the cloud with pre-built foundation models.
Pitfalls: Focusing only on the ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù without grasping the underlying concepts.
Tips: Use AWS‚Äôs extensive documentation and online tutorials. Start with simple use cases and gradually increase complexity.



IV. Projects
Hands-on experience is essential. Build projects to solidify your understanding and showcase your skills.

Portfolio Website:

Host your website files on S3, configure a custom domain, and implement versioning.
Tips: Use this project to learn about S3 security features, static website hosting, and DNS management.


Task Tracking System:

Use an EC2 instance to host a web application (built with Python, for example) that connects to a database (using RDS for a relational database).
Tips: This project will help you understand application deployment, database integration, and basic web development.


Image Sharing App:

Store images in S3. Implement user authentication and authorisation using IAM.
Tips: Focus on security best practices for handling user data and access control.



V. Certifications
Industry certifications validate your skills and enhance your credibility.

Cloud Practitioner: A foundational certification that demonstrates basic understanding of cloud concepts.
Solutions Architect (Associate/Professional): Focuses on designing and deploying scalable and reliable systems on AWS.
Pitfalls: Relying solely on certifications without practical experience.
Tips: Use certifications to guide your learning and demonstrate your commitment to the field.

VI. Essential Cloud Tools

Infrastructure as Code (IaC):

Terraform: Learn to define and manage your infrastructure using code. This enables automation, reproducibility, and version control.
Pitfalls: Manually configuring resources through the AWS console, which is not scalable or maintainable.
Tips: Embrace IaC from the beginning. Practice writing Terraform configurations for your projects.


CI/CD Pipelines:

GitHub and GitHub Actions: Implement continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) to automate code deployments and testing.
Pitfalls: Deploying code manually, which is prone to errors and inconsistencies.
Tips: Set up automated build and test pipelines for your projects using GitHub Actions.



VII. Advanced AWS Services

AWS Lambda: Serverless compute service for running code without managing servers.
API Gateway: Create and manage APIs for your applications.
DynamoDB: NoSQL database service for high-scale applications.
SageMaker: Platform for building, training, and deploying machine learning models.
Pitfalls: Jumping into advanced services without a solid foundation in core services.
Tips: Start with simple Lambda functions and gradually explore more complex use cases.

VIII. Complex Project Building

Event-driven Notification System: Build a system that uses Lambda, DynamoDB, and SNS (Simple Notification Service) to trigger notifications based on events.
Book Recommendation Engine: Develop an AI-powered system that recommends books to users based on their preferences and historical data.
Pitfalls: Undertaking overly ambitious projects too early in your learning journey.
Tips: Break down complex projects into smaller, manageable tasks. Focus on building a functional system first, then iteratively add features.

articles/project-notes/Cure-Dolly-Japane.title: Cure Dolly Japanese Learning 317fc89405cf4cf5baba2c11498a75cf
articles/project-notes/Cure-Dolly-Japane.content:
Cure Dolly Japanese Learning
All language is comprised of two types of sentences.
A is B
We can provide additional information about A and/or B, but these two forms are the base. We can vary the tense or value (+ -)
A is the carriage or subject of the sentence. B is the thing the carriage is
Sakura ga nihonjin
A does B
In Japanese „Åå (ga) is the linchpin of every sentence, even when you cannot see it. It is used to hook A and B to form a sentence
Example
Sakura walks
Sakura ga aruku
„ÅÇ„Çã„Åè (aruku) walks
‚Äúmainly comes after nouns and indicates the subject of a sentence. It shows who does the action that comes after the subject.‚Äù NHK World Japan
Connective da. ‚ÄúTo be‚Äù. Connects the verb and complement
„Å† (da) is another core particle. It is the simplest form of „Åß„Åô (desu) which is how it is used in most speech. It tell us that A ‚Äúis‚Äù B. Using it with the wrong subject confuses the meaning in context because B is not always A.
Sakura ga nihonjin da
Adjective „ÅÑ (i)
i is added to the end of a word to make it descriptive.
In english, a lot of adjective end with y as well. Happy, sunny etc
„ÅÑ mean is-adjective. So it replaces ga „Åå
When using a „ÅÑ adjective, „Å† is not necessary.
Lesson 2: Omitting the subject
The invisible carriage
Replacing the subject of the sentence with something like ‚Äúit‚Äù. While it is used in English, in Japanese, it can be omitted
Japanese relies more on topic and context
Essentially, subject pronouns are not crucial in japanese
Example
Watashi ga Abdullahi da(de su) = Abdullahi da(desu)
Watashi ga becomes invisible
„Çí„ÄÄThe wo or o carriage
It represents the object of the sentence
wo/o is not part of A is B or A does B. it adds context to A or B
Example
A                                 B
watashi-ga keeki-wo taberu
here, wo tells us more about the B part of the sentence. Cake is what is being eaten
The invisible carriage allows us convert this to
keeki-wo taberu
Lesson 3
the wa particle is a non-logical particle
Wa is not a core sentence composition. It is not part of A, B or wo. A noun marked with was is not part of the sentence logic,
Wa is a flag. It only indicates that a noun is the topic of the sentence
wa = as for. as for me, as for cars, as for this topic
Example
Watashi wa, Amerikajin da
As for me, am American. This is wrong in both English and Japanese
This is because we are omitting the actual sentence carriage ‚Äúga‚Äù
The invisible carriage here still exists to make this make sense. The full sentence would be
watashi wa, (watashi) ga, amerikajin da
The logical trio
„Çí (wo), „Åå (ga), „Å´ (ni)
„Åå (ga) tells us who does what
„Çí (wo) - what it is being done to
„Å´ (ni) - ultimate target of the action
All sentences have ga, but not necessarily wi or ni

Ga is always present, even when it is invisible

articles/project-notes/DIY-Hair-and-Scal.content:
DIY Hair and Scalp Care Products for 4C Afro Hair
DIY Leave-In Conditioner for Thick, Coarse, and Dry Hair
Carrier oils: Choose 2-3 carrier oils depending on your desired result.
Hydrating agents: Aloe vera gel, glycerin, honey, or panthenol (vitamin B5) will lock in moisture and prevent dryness.
Strength-building proteins: Wheat germ oil, rice bran oil, or hydrolyzed silk proteins will help strengthen and prevent breakage.
Detangling agents: Apple cider vinegar or slippery elm powder will reduce frizz and make combing easier.
Preservatives: Optiphen Plus or Geogard ECT will prevent your conditioner from spoiling too quickly.
Ingredients and Ratios
Carrier Oils (2-3 oils):
For deep hydration, try coconut oil, avocado oil, or olive oil (use sparingly). For lighter options, choose jojoba oil, grapeseed oil, or argan oil.

Start with 1/2 cup of your main carrier oil (e.g., coconut oil) or
Add 2-4 tablespoons of other carrier oils (e.g., avocado oil, jojoba oil) to balance the consistency and benefits

Hydrating Agents:

1/4 to 1/2 cup of aloe vera gel or glycerin
1-2 tablespoons of honey or panthenol (vitamin B5)

Strength-Building Proteins:

1 tablespoon of wheat germ oil, rice bran oil, or hydrolyzed silk protein

Detangling Agents:

1-2 tablespoons of apple cider vinegar or 1/2 teaspoon of slippery elm powder

Preservative:

10 drops of Optiphen Plus or Geogard ECT

Instructions

Combine your chosen carrier oils in a sterile bottle or container.
Add the hydrating agents, starting with the lower amounts and increasing as needed to achieve your desired consistency.
Incorporate the strength-building protein and detangling agent.
Add the preservative and mix thoroughly to ensure all ingredients are well-blended.
Transfer the leave-in conditioner to a clean, airtight spray bottle.

Tips and Considerations

Adjust the ingredient amounts to suit your hair‚Äôs specific needs and preferences.
Perform a patch test on a small section of your hair before using the full recipe, especially if you have sensitive skin or scalp.
Store the leave-in conditioner in a cool, dark place for up to 2 months.
Shake the bottle well before each use to ensure the ingredients are properly mixed.
You can customize the scent by adding a few drops of your favorite essential oil.

This DIY leave-in conditioner is designed to provide long-lasting hydration, strength, and detangling benefits for thick, coarse, and dry hair. Enjoy your personalized hair care solution!
DIY Hair and Scalp Care Products for 4C Afro Hair
Daily Hydrating Hair Mist
Ingredients:

1/2 cup distilled water
2-3 tablespoons aloe vera juice
1-2 tablespoons vegetable glycerin
1-2 teaspoons jojoba oil
5-10 drops lavender essential oil (optional for fragrance and scalp health)

Instructions:

In a clean spray bottle, combine the distilled water, aloe vera juice, vegetable glycerin, jojoba oil, and lavender essential oil (if using).
Close the bottle tightly and shake well to mix all the ingredients thoroughly.
Use this hydrating mist daily to refresh and moisturize your hair and scalp. Shake well before each use and spray onto damp or dry hair, focusing on areas prone to dryness and scalp irritation.

Shelf Life and Storage:
This hydrating hair mist can be stored in a cool, dark place for up to 2 months. Be sure to shake the bottle well before each use.
Safety Considerations:
Perform a patch test on a small section of your hair and scalp before using the full recipe, especially if you have sensitive skin or scalp. Discontinue use if any irritation occurs.
Daily Scalp Massage Oil
Ingredients:

2-3 tablespoons coconut oil
1-2 tablespoons castor oil
1-2 teaspoons peppermint oil
1-2 teaspoons tea tree oil

Instructions:

In a small bowl, combine the coconut oil, castor oil, peppermint oil, and tea tree oil. Mix well until thoroughly blended.
To use, apply a small amount of the oil mixture to your fingertips and massage it gently into your scalp using circular motions. Focus on areas of dryness or irritation.
Leave the oil on your scalp for at least 15-30 minutes, or overnight for a deeper treatment.
Rinse the oil out thoroughly with lukewarm water and shampoo as usual.

Shelf Life and Storage:
This scalp massage oil can be stored in a cool, dark place for up to 3 months. Be sure to tightly seal the container between uses.
Safety Considerations:
Perform a patch test on a small area of your scalp before using the full recipe, especially if you have sensitive skin. Discontinue use if any irritation occurs.
Daily Moisturizing Hair Cream
Ingredients:

1/4 to 1/3 cup shea butter
2-3 tablespoons mango butter
1-2 tablespoons avocado oil
1-2 tablespoons argan oil
1-2 teaspoons honey

Instructions:

In a heat-safe bowl, melt the shea butter and mango butter using a double boiler or microwave until fully melted.
Allow the mixture to cool slightly, then add the avocado oil, argan oil, and honey. Stir well to combine.
Transfer the mixture to a clean, airtight container and let it solidify at room temperature.
To use, scoop out a small amount of the hair cream and apply it to damp or dry hair, focusing on the ends and any areas of dryness. Style as desired.

Shelf Life and Storage:
This moisturizing hair cream can be stored in a cool, dark place for up to 4 months. Be sure to tightly seal the container between uses.
Safety Considerations:
Perform a patch test on a small section of your hair and scalp before using the full recipe, especially if you have sensitive skin. Discontinue use if any irritation occurs.These DIY hair and scalp care products are designed to provide daily hydration, nourishment, and moisture for 4C Afro hair. Incorporate them into your routine to enjoy the benefits of healthy, hydrated hair and a soothed, nourished scalp.

articles/project-notes/Etymology-1de635c.title: Etymology 1de635c581e08079a7b4c70edb1597f3
articles/project-notes/Etymology-1de635c.content:
Etymology
muse(v.)‚Äúto reflect, ponder, meditate; to be absorbed in thought,‚Äù mid-14c., from Old French muser (12c.) ‚Äúto ponder, dream, wonder; loiter, waste time,‚Äù which is of uncertain origin; the explanation in Diez and Skeat is literally ‚Äúto stand with one‚Äôs nose in the air‚Äù (or, possibly, ‚Äúto sniff about‚Äù like a dog who has lost the scent), from muse ‚Äúmuzzle,‚Äù from Gallo-Roman *musa ‚Äúsnout,‚Äù itself a word of unknown origin. The modern word probably has been influenced in sense by muse (n.). Related: Mused; musing.
also from mid-14c.
Muse(n.)late 14c., ‚Äúone of the nine Muses of classical mythology,‚Äù daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne, protectors of the arts; from Old French Muse and directly from Latin Musa, from Greek Mousa, ‚Äúthe Muse,‚Äù also ‚Äúmusic, song,‚Äù ultimately from PIE root *men- (1) ‚Äúto think.‚Äù Meaning ‚Äúinspiring goddess of a particular poet‚Äù (with a lower-case m-) is from late 14c.
The traditional names and specialties of the nine Muses are: Calliope (epic poetry), Clio (history), Erato (love poetry, lyric art), Euterpe (music, especially flute), Melpomene (tragedy), Polymnia (hymns), Terpsichore (dance), Thalia (comedy), Urania (astronomy).
amuse(v.)late 15c., ‚Äúto divert the attention, beguile, delude,‚Äù from Old French amuser ‚Äúfool, tease, hoax, entrap; make fun of,‚Äù literally ‚Äúcause to muse‚Äù (as a distraction), from a ‚Äúat, to‚Äù (from Latin ad, but here probably a causal prefix) + muser ‚Äúponder, stare fixedly‚Äù (see muse (v.)).
The original English senses are obsolete; the meaning ‚Äúdivert from serious business, tickle the fancy of‚Äù is recorded from 1630s, but through 18c. the primary meaning was ‚Äúdeceive, cheat‚Äù by first occupying the attention. ‚ÄúThe word was not in reg. use bef. 1600, and was not used by Shakespere‚Äù [OED]. Bemuse retains more of the original meaning. Greek amousos meant ‚Äúwithout Muses,‚Äù hence ‚Äúuneducated.‚Äù

articles/project-notes/Fabric-Guide.title: Fabric Guide
articles/project-notes/Fabric-Guide.content:
Tags: miscellaneous
Fabrics of different types have different handling properties
Content
Hemp

Alternative Names: Cannabis sativa
Description: A strong, durable natural fiber derived from the hemp plant. Has a coarse, textured feel.
Best for: Outerwear, bags, ropes, canvas.
Advantages: Highly durable, breathable, and environmentally-friendly. Disadvantages: Can feel rough and scratchy against the skin.
Quality Identification: Look for a tight, even weave and minimal imperfections. Avoid pilling or fraying.
Best Blends: Hemp is often blended with softer fibers like cotton or linen to improve comfort and drape.
Seasons: Hemp is suitable for all seasons due to its breathability and durability.
Image: [hemp fabric]
Care: Hemp is machine washable in cold water and can be line dried. Avoid high heat.

Bamboo

Alternative Names: Bamboo fiber, bamboo rayon
Description: A soft, silky fabric made from the cellulose of bamboo plants. Has a smooth, lightweight feel.
Best for: Clothing, bedding, towels.
Advantages: Extremely soft, breathable, and moisture-wicking. Disadvantages: Can be more expensive than other natural fibers.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture without pilling or roughness.
Best Blends: Bamboo blends well with cotton, linen, or other natural fibers to enhance softness and breathability.
Seasons: Bamboo is suitable for all seasons due to its temperature regulating properties.
Image: [bamboo fabric]
Care: Bamboo is machine washable in cold water and can be tumble dried on low heat.

Ramie

Alternative Names: China grass
Description: A lustrous, durable natural fiber extracted from the ramie plant. Has a crisp, linen-like texture.
Best for: Shirts, dresses, home textiles.
Advantages: Highly absorbent, wrinkle-resistant, and durable. Disadvantages: Can feel stiff and rough against the skin.
Quality Identification: Look for a tight, even weave and a smooth, lustrous appearance.
Best Blends: Ramie is often blended with cotton or linen to improve softness and drape.
Seasons: Ramie is best suited for spring and summer due to its lightweight, breathable properties.
Image: [ramie fabric]
Care: Ramie is machine washable in cold water and can be line dried. Avoid high heat.

Linen

Alternative Names: None
Description: A lightweight, breathable fabric made from the fibers of the flax plant. Has a crisp, textured feel.
Best for: Shirts, dresses, suits, home textiles.
Advantages: Highly absorbent, durable, and temperature regulating. Disadvantages: Wrinkles easily and can feel stiff.
Quality Identification: Look for an even, tight weave and a smooth, lustrous appearance.
Best Blends: Linen is often blended with cotton or silk to improve softness and reduce wrinkling.
Seasons: Linen is best suited for spring and summer due to its lightweight, breathable properties.
Image: [linen fabric]
Care: Linen is machine washable in cold water and can be line dried. Use a warm iron to minimize wrinkles.

Tencel (Lyocell)

Alternative Names: Lyocell
Description: A soft, silky fabric made from the regenerated cellulose of wood pulp. Has a smooth, drapey feel.
Best for: Clothing, bedding, activewear.
Advantages: Highly absorbent, breathable, and environmentally-friendly. Disadvantages: Can be more expensive than other fabrics.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture without pilling or roughness.
Best Blends: Tencel blends well with cotton, linen, or other natural fibers to enhance softness and breathability.
Seasons: Tencel is suitable for all seasons due to its temperature regulating properties.
Image: [tencel fabric]
Care: Tencel is machine washable in cold water and can be tumble dried on low heat.

Cashmere

Alternative Names: None
Description: A luxuriously soft, fine fabric made from the downy undercoat of Cashmere goats. Has an exceptionally soft, lightweight feel.
Best for: Sweaters, scarves, coats.
Advantages: Extremely soft, warm, and durable. Disadvantages: Can be very expensive.
Quality Identification: Look for a dense, uniform weave and a silky, plush texture.
Best Blends: Cashmere is often blended with wool or other fibers to improve durability and reduce cost.
Seasons: Cashmere is best suited for fall and winter due to its exceptional warmth.
Image: [cashmere fabric]
Care: Cashmere requires gentle hand washing or dry cleaning to maintain its soft texture.

Wool

Alternative Names: None
Description: A natural fiber obtained from the fleece of sheep and other animals. Has a soft, insulating feel.
Best for: Sweaters, coats, suits, blankets.
Advantages: Warm, durable, and moisture-wicking. Disadvantages: Can be itchy for some and requires special care.
Quality Identification: Look for a dense, uniform weave and a soft, springy texture.
Best Blends: Wool is often blended with synthetic fibers like polyester or nylon to improve durability and reduce itchiness.
Seasons: Wool is best suited for fall and winter due to its exceptional warmth.
Image: [wool fabric]
Care: Wool requires gentle hand washing or dry cleaning. Avoid high heat and harsh detergents.

Silk

Alternative Names: None
Description: A luxurious, smooth fabric made from the fibers of silkworm cocoons. Has a soft, lustrous feel.
Best for: Blouses, dresses, scarves, sleepwear.
Advantages: Exceptionally soft, drapes beautifully, and has a natural sheen. Disadvantages: Can be delicate and expensive.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture and a lustrous appearance.
Best Blends: Silk is often blended with other fibers like wool or cotton to improve durability and reduce cost.
Seasons: Lightweight silk is best suited for spring and summer, while heavier silk works well for fall and winter.
Image: [silk fabric]
Care: Silk requires gentle hand washing or dry cleaning. Avoid high heat and harsh detergents.

Polyester

Alternative Names: None
Description: A synthetic fabric known for its durability and wrinkle resistance. Has a smooth, slightly shiny appearance.
Best for: Activewear, outerwear, blouses.
Advantages: Highly durable, wrinkle-resistant, and easy to care for. Disadvantages: Can feel less breathable than natural fibers.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture and a slight sheen.
Best Blends: Polyester is often blended with natural fibers like cotton or wool to improve breathability and comfort.
Seasons: Polyester can be worn year-round, depending on the garment type.
Image: [polyester fabric]
Care: Polyester is machine washable and can be tumble dried on low heat.

Cotton

Alternative Names: None
Description: A soft, breathable natural fiber derived from the cotton plant. Has a lightweight, slightly textured feel.
Best for: T-shirts, shirts, dresses, lightweight pants.
Advantages: Soft, breathable, and durable. Disadvantages: Can wrinkle easily and shrink if not properly cared for.
Quality Identification: Look for a tight, even weave and a soft, slightly napped texture.
Best Blends: Cotton is often blended with synthetic fibers like polyester to improve durability and wrinkle resistance.
Seasons: Cotton is best suited for spring and summer due to its lightweight, breathable properties.
Image: [cotton fabric]
Care: Cotton is machine washable in cold water and can be tumble dried on low heat.

Leather

Alternative Names: None
Description: A durable, flexible material created by tanning animal hides. Has a smooth, supple feel.
Best for: Jackets, bags, shoes, accessories.
Advantages: Highly durable, weather-resistant, and stylish. Disadvantages: Can be expensive and require special care.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture and a supple feel. Avoid any cracks or blemishes.
Best Blends: Leather is often blended with synthetic materials like polyester or nylon to improve durability and reduce cost.
Seasons: Leather can be worn year-round, depending on the garment type.
Image: [leather fabric]
Care: Leather requires specialized cleaning and conditioning products to maintain its appearance and longevity.

Rayon

Alternative Names: Viscose
Description: A semi-synthetic fabric made from regenerated cellulose fibers. Has a smooth, drapey feel.
Best for: Dresses, blouses, skirts.
Advantages: Soft, breathable, and drapes well. Disadvantages: Can be less durable than natural fibers.
Quality Identification: Look for a consistent, smooth texture and a soft, flowing drape.
Best Blends: Rayon is often blended with cotton or other natural fibers to improve breathability and durability.
Seasons: Rayon is best suited for spring and summer due to its lightweight, breathable properties.
Image: [rayon fabric]
Care: Rayon is machine washable in cold water and can be tumble dried on low heat.

Citations:
[1] officinepaladino.com/trends/5-different-types-of-wool-blend-fabrics/
[2] www.printful.com/blog/guide-to-cotton-polyester-and-blended-fabrics
[3] www.hawthornintl.com/fabric-guide
[4] www.commonobjective.co/article/quick-guide-to-different-types-of-textile-fibres
[5] site.extension.uga.edu/textiles/textile-basics/fiber-types/

articles/project-notes/First-90-days-9fa.title: First 90 days 9fac5cdbd65349528d312289bcac61e3
articles/project-notes/First-90-days-9fa.content:
First 90 days
First 90
I was going to write this article after my first 90 days as a product manager but at some point during that period, I realised that while I believed I understood what to do, I needed time to assess and reflect on the steps I took in that time in order to truly deliver value to you dear reader. And so I spent another 90 days understanding not only how I had spent those first 3 months, but the outcomes and what I could have done to improve on them.
My awakening to product management as a career path which I have discussed in a previous article, happened late in 2021. Since then I have attended a Product Management bootcamp, completed several Udemy courses on related topics and been building in stealth with a great team. I have also been an Associate Product Manager at Decagon since April 2022, and it is from this experience that this article draws from.
I particularly love working at Decagon because it is a mission-led organisation looking to make Nigeria into the next tech-capital of the world by training elite software engineers for the world‚Äôs tech talent market. It is easy to appreciate how transformative it could be for not just Nigeria, but the world One thing that I particularly love about working at Decagon is that it is a mission-led organisation looking to make Nigeria into the next tech-capital of the world by training software engineers. Anyone can immediately appreciate just how how transformative succeeding at this would be. What this means is that your KPIs are not just deliverables to further the business, they are literally checkpoints on the road to change the world.
Because of the nature of this mission, I am quite often working with a lot of junior and unskilled developers. It is my job to train not only their product sense, but their understanding of the scrum framework and the agile software development process.
This is peculiar because as a recent addition to the Product Management scene myself, I am spending my learning period teaching people this should be in my learning phase. Yet, this experience has forced me to upskill rather rapidly. I have built and iterated more products in the last 6 months than some product managers do in their first 2 years.
Understand the business
This probably goes without saying but the first thing you need to do is to understand the business you are in.
Find out all there is to know about your company, not just the product. You need to understand the organisation‚Äôs goals, objectives, what your stakeholders value. You need to understand the market. You will have all sort of ideas and features because you have fresh eyes, but what market is your product addressing and what are the peculiarities of that market
Be humble
If your company is not at literAL DAY ONE, you need to understand that many of your ideas have probably been considered by more experienced and senior members of the business and may already be in the roadmap. You need to understand the visions and roadmap. Talk to people and find out what they are working on and what they‚Äôve worked on. If you have a product team, do not go straight to your boss with an idea you haven‚Äôt thought of Collaborate and it will make your proposal stronger and give it more weight that you were able to get buy in from someone your manager probably already trusts
Forget the Job Description
Build a Team
Depending on your team size.
Better PM
and a and so my unofficial title has really been Product Manager/Scrum Master vs Agile coach. I have a lot to learn and yet I have learned a lot as well. Here‚Äôs what I learned about how to spend your first 90 days as a PM
with a gr side project that is still I began my first structured PM role at Decagon just 6 months ago so needless to say, I still have a lot to learn. One amazing thing about my current organisation however is simply the amount of learning opportunities available. As a training institute itself, Decagon is no stranger to the importance of upskilling and continued education. Not to mention that I have an amazing line manager with who I believe I share similar values in terms professional commitment and development and who I am constantly learning from.
One peculiar thing about my career is that I work a lot of nascent developers myself. As a Product Manager, it falls on me not just to own the product outcome, but the individua outcomes of the team members as well. I must make sure that not only is the development team creating value for the product, but that the product is creating value for the development team.

articles/project-notes/Hobbies-1db635c58.title: Hobbies 1db635c581e0802b959bfbe11fb1593f
articles/project-notes/Hobbies-1db635c58.content:
Hobbies
Origami (focusing on mathematical/complex):

Starting Point: Get some standard origami paper (or even just square paper like sticky notes or cut-up A4). Find a reliable online tutorial (YouTube is great for visuals) or a beginner‚Äôs book specifically for models that go a bit beyond the super simple crane or boat. Look for models labelled ‚Äúeasy-intermediate‚Äù or that introduce specific base folds (like the Bird Base or Frog Base). Practise making clean, precise folds ‚Äì precision is key as you move to more complex models.
Sustainability: Highly sustainable. Origami has immense depth, from mastering complex existing models (some take hours!) to exploring modular origami (creating large structures from many identical units) and even designing your own models (where the mathematical aspect really comes in). There‚Äôs a large online community sharing designs and techniques.

Amateur Etymology:

Starting Point: Get access to a good online etymological dictionary (like Etymonline.com or the etymology section of Wiktionary). Simply start with words you use every day or words you‚Äôre curious about and look them up. Follow the threads ‚Äì if a word comes from Latin, look up the Latin root and see what other English words come from it.
Sustainability: Very sustainable. Language is constantly evolving, and there are endless words to explore. You can specialise in words from a particular source language (like Greek or Old English), words related to a specific topic (like science or cooking), or delve into the history of idioms and phrases. It‚Äôs a never-ending process of discovery.

Advanced Logic Puzzles:

Starting Point: Pick one type of advanced logic puzzle that looks interesting (like Slitherlink, Hitori, Kakuro, or Nonograms). Find a website, app, or book that offers puzzles of that type specifically labelled as ‚ÄúEasy‚Äù or ‚ÄúBeginner.‚Äù Learn the rules thoroughly and work through those easy puzzles to get a feel for the basic deduction techniques.
Sustainability: Extremely sustainable. There are thousands of different logic puzzle types, and within each type, the difficulty can be scaled up to be incredibly challenging. Competitive puzzling offers another layer of engagement. You will constantly find new types to learn and harder puzzles to test your skills on.

Ciphership and Cryptanalysis (Classical):

Starting Point: Begin by learning the simplest historical ciphers: the Caesar cipher and the Rail Fence cipher. Understand how they work. Immediately follow this by learning their corresponding cryptanalysis methods (like trying all possible shifts for Caesar). Find online resources or introductory books on ‚Äúclassical cryptography‚Äù that provide practice messages for these simple ciphers. Try encrypting and decrypting your own messages.
Sustainability: Highly sustainable. While the historical ciphers themselves are finite, the process of learning them, understanding the history of code-making and breaking, and applying the cryptanalysis techniques to solve practice problems offers deep engagement. You can progress through increasingly complex historical ciphers (Vigen√®re, Playfair, etc.) and learn more sophisticated breaking techniques. The blend of history, logic, and puzzle-solving provides lasting interest.

Formal Logic and Proof Study:

Starting Point: Find an introductory resource specifically on Propositional Logic. This is the foundational level. Look for free online courses (like those sometimes offered on platforms like Coursera or edX, or open university materials) or a beginner-friendly textbook on Symbolic or Formal Logic. Focus on understanding the basic logical symbols (AND, OR, NOT, IF‚Ä¶THEN) and, crucially, start working through the exercises on translating sentences into symbols and constructing simple proofs using the first few rules of inference you learn.
Sustainability: Highly sustainable. Formal logic is a deep academic field with many branches (Predicate Logic, Modal Logic, etc.). As a hobbyist, you can spend years working through different logical systems, exploring proof techniques, and even touching on related areas like the philosophy or mathematics of logic. The challenge and the satisfaction of constructing rigorous proofs provide ongoing engagement.

Amateur Anatomy and Physiology Study:

What it involves: Learning the structure (anatomy) and function (physiology) of the human body. This can range from understanding the major organ systems down to the cellular level.
Starting Point: Get a good introductory resource. Look for a widely used first-year university-level Anatomy and Physiology textbook (libraries are excellent for this, or look for affordable older editions or free online versions like OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology). Many excellent websites, apps, and YouTube channels offer clear explanations and visualisations of anatomy. Start with a foundational system like the skeletal system (bones) or muscular system, which provide a good framework. Focus on learning the names and locations of key structures and their basic functions.
Sustainability: Highly sustainable. The human body is immensely complex. You can spend years studying different systems (nervous, cardiovascular, endocrine, etc.), delving into microscopic anatomy (histology), or exploring the physiology of how systems work together. There‚Äôs always more to learn.

articles/project-notes/How-Models-work--.title: How Models work - Kaggle 7ea8163d1df94d69aeaa21b713f926a5
articles/project-notes/How-Models-work--.content:
How Models work - Kaggle
Start with decision tree.
A decision tree Auto with a question condition
If yes ‚áí Do this
If no ‚áí Do that
The process of capturing these patterns from a date set is called ‚Äúfitting‚Äù or ‚Äútraining‚Äù your model
The data used to do this is called a ‚Äútraining data‚Äù The prediction at the bottom of the th decision tree is a leaf.
Using Pandas
import pandas as pd
Pandas gives access to DataFrame. Df is a spreadsheet/table database.
The next step is to load your data using the filepath
pd.read-csv()

üí° a good way to simplify this is
Store the filepath to a python variable
Store the loaded data as well to a variable
Eg weatherdata = filepath
Weatherdf = pd.read-csv(weatherdata)

Call the .describe() method to get a summary description of the dataframe
Count, mean std, min, 23%, 50%, 75%, max
Suppose that our aim is to predict a value given the information we have in our dataframe, we must select a prediction target
In processing and analysing our data, we will need to select subsets of that data. There are 2 ways

Dot notation ‚Üí for predictors targets
Selecting column list ‚Üí select features

Prediction targets and features.
Dot notation
df.name ‚Üí This calls the ‚Äòname‚Äô column in the df dataframe
The list of column values is called a Pandas series
When we want to predict a value using our dataset, we can set variable ‚Äòy‚Äô to the desired prediction target column using y = df.name
Limitations
Because the table name is called like an attribute, this method of accessing columns is called attribute access
The columns that can be called must conform to python syntax.
A better to call a column is df[‚Äòname‚Äô]
Features are all other columns with which we want to determine our prediction
set
x = df[‚Äòname‚Äô, ‚Äòage‚Äô, ‚Äòroom‚Äô]
set dependent y and independent ‚Äòx‚Äô variable.
. describe() .head()
Pandas ‚Üí process data, set independent and dependent variables
Scikit-learn- Create Models using dataframes
Pandas ‚Üí Scikit-learn
Model building steps
Define - define the type of model
Fit - Capture patterns in available data
Predict -
Evaluate - How accurate is the model?
To create a model
fist set & y = df[‚Äòcol‚Äô]
then set x = df[‚Äòcol 1‚Äô, ‚Äòcol 2‚Äô, ‚Äòcol n‚Äô]
Import
# Data Loading Code Hidden Here
import pandas as pd
 
# Load data
melbourne_file_path = '../input/melbourne-housing-snapshot/melb_data.csv'
melbourne_data = pd.read_csv(melbourne_file_path) 
# Filter rows with missing price values
filtered_melbourne_data = melbourne_data.dropna(axis=0)
# Choose target and features
y = filtered_melbourne_data.Price
melbourne_features = ['Rooms', 'Bathroom', 'Landsize', 'BuildingArea', 
                        'YearBuilt', 'Lattitude', 'Longtitude']
X = filtered_melbourne_data[melbourne_features]
 
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeRegressor
# Define model
melbourne_model = DecisionTreeRegressor()
# Fit model
melbourne_model.fit(X, y)
 
DecisionTreeRegressor()
# Once we have a model, here is how we calculate the mean absolute error:
 
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error
 
predicted_home_prices = melbourne_model.predict(X)
mean_absolute_error(y, predicted_home_prices)
434.71594577146544
Model Validation
After creating the model, model validation helps evaluate the quality of the model
A model‚Äôs quality is determined by its predictive accuracy. i.e how close to reality is the prediction.

üí° Mean Absolute Error (MAE)
Find the error for each prediction:
Error = Actual - Predicted
Convert error to positive by taking the absolute value
|Error|
Take the average of all errors:
|Error 1| + |Error 2| + |Error n| / n

If you use a single training dataset to train a model, the system may find false correlations in the data that will always hold true within the sample dataset. But the model is only truly valuable if it can predict data in the real world
One way to handle this is to split the training data into two sets, train the model using one set and predict data in the other set
train_test_split

articles/project-notes/How-to-Wash-Your-.content:
How to Wash Your Face
Skincare Routine Guide
Here is a comprehensive step-by-step skincare routine guide incorporating the information provided:
Morning Routine

Wash Your Hands: Start by thoroughly washing your hands to ensure they are clean before touching your face.
Prep Your Face: Use warm water to prep your face and open up your pores.
Use Water: Instead of a face wash, use only water to cleanse your face in the morning.
Dry with a Face Towel: Gently pat your face dry with a clean, soft face towel.
Apply Serum: Apply your chosen serum(s) targeting specific concerns, such as hyperpigmentation or puffiness.
Moisturize: Apply a moisturizer suitable for your skin type, avoiding overlapping with any active ingredients in your serums. If the weather is humid, you may skip this step
Apply Sunscreen: Finish your morning routine by applying a generous amount of sunscreen to protect your skin from harmful UV rays.
Drink Water: Remember to stay hydrated by drinking a glass of water.

Evening Routine

Wash Your Hands: Start by washing your hands.
Prep Your Face: Use warm water to prep your face and open up your pores.
Use the Face Wash: Apply the face wash to your skin, massaging it in for 45-60 seconds, focusing on your nose, forehead, cheeks, chin, neck, and beard area.
Rinse with Lukewarm Water: Rinse off the face wash with lukewarm water.
Dry with a Face Towel: Gently pat your face dry with a clean, soft face towel.
Exfoliate: Incorporate exfoliating 2-3 times per week to remove dead skin cells and unclog pores.
Mist: Apply a hydrating mist containing ingredients like glycerin or essences.
Apply Serums: Apply your chosen serum(s) targeting specific concerns, such as hyperpigmentation or puffiness.
Apply Eye Cream: Use a targeted eye cream containing ingredients like retinol or caffeine. If the eye cream is thicker than the moisturizer, it should go on after it.
Moisturize: Apply a moisturizer suitable for your skin type, avoiding overlapping with any active ingredients in your serums. If the weather is humid, you may skip this step.
Face Oils (Optional): If your skin is extremely dry, you can apply a face oil.

Remember, this comprehensive skincare routine should be followed both in the morning and at night for optimal results. Consistency is key to achieving healthy, glowing skin.
Here is a comparison of the key skincare ingredients you asked about:
Hyaluronic Acid:

A powerful humectant that can hold up to 1,000 times its weight in water, providing deep, long-lasting hydration.[1][2][3]
Helps reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles by plumping and firming the skin.[1][2][3]
Improves skin elasticity and promotes a more youthful, radiant complexion.[1][2][3]

Niacinamide:

A form of vitamin B3 that helps regulate oil production, minimize pores, and even out skin tone.[1][2][4]
Has anti-inflammatory properties that can reduce redness and treat acne.[1][2][4]
Strengthens the skin‚Äôs protective barrier and protects against environmental damage.[1][2][4]

Vitamin C:

A potent antioxidant that neutralizes free radicals to prevent collagen breakdown and premature aging.[2][5]
Brightens the skin, fades dark spots, and inhibits melanin production for a more even complexion.[2][5]
Works synergistically with vitamin E to provide enhanced protection against oxidative stress.[2][3]

Vitamin E:

Another antioxidant that helps maintain the skin‚Äôs barrier function and improve the appearance of scars and sun damage.[3]
Provides additional protection against environmental aggressors when used with vitamin C.[2][3]

Retinol:

A form of vitamin A that stimulates collagen production and cell turnover to reduce fine lines, wrinkles, and hyperpigmentation.
Can cause dryness and irritation, especially for sensitive skin, so it‚Äôs important to start with low concentrations and build tolerance.

Kojic Acid:

Derived from fungi, it inhibits melanin production to fade dark spots and even out skin tone.
Has mild exfoliating properties that can improve texture and brightness.
May cause redness or sensitivity in some individuals.

Arbutin:

A natural skin-lightening agent that reduces melanin production to target hyperpigmentation.
Considered a gentler alternative to hydroquinone, another common skin-lightening ingredient.
Effective but can take several weeks to see results.

Caffeine:

Provides a temporary tightening and de-puffing effect when applied topically.
Can help reduce the appearance of under-eye bags and dark circles.
Works best when combined with other soothing, hydrating ingredients.

Licorice Root:

Contains glabridin, which has anti-inflammatory and skin-brightening properties.
Helps calm redness and irritation while fading discoloration.
Suitable for sensitive skin types.

AHA (Alpha Hydroxy Acids):

Water-soluble acids derived from sugary fruits
Exfoliate the surface of the skin to improve texture, reduce fine lines, and even out tone
Examples include glycolic acid and lactic acid
Generally safe for all skin types, but may cause initial dryness or irritation

BHA (Beta Hydroxy Acids):

Oil-soluble acids like salicylic acid
Penetrate deeper into the pores to remove excess oil and dead skin cells
Effective for treating acne, blackheads, and sun damage
May be better suited for oily or acne-prone skin

PHA (Polyhydroxy Acids):

Larger molecule size than AHAs and BHAs
Provide gentle exfoliation with less irritation
Help improve skin hydration and barrier function
Suitable for sensitive skin types

Ceramides:

Natural lipids found in the skin‚Äôs outer layer
Help strengthen and repair the skin barrier
Improve moisture retention and prevent water loss
Beneficial for dry, dehydrated, or compromised skin

Salicylic Acid (a type of BHA):

Oil-soluble, penetrates into pores
Has anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties
Effective for treating acne, reducing redness and swelling
May cause dryness if overused, so should be introduced gradually

In summary, AHAs and BHAs are both exfoliating acids that improve skin texture and tone, but differ in their solubility and target skin concerns. PHAs offer a gentler alternative, while ceramides help strengthen the skin barrier. Salicylic acid is a specific type of BHA with unique benefits for acne-prone skin.
Citations:
[1] Hyaluronic Acid & Salicylic Acid - What are they Good For? skincancerderm.com/hyaluronic-acid-salicylic-acid-what-are-they-good-for/
[2] Why You Need to Know the Difference Between Hyaluronic Acid and Salicy myeclatshop.com/blogs/the-eclat-edit/hyaluronic-acid-vs-salicylic-acid
[3] Skincare Acids Guide - lluillui www.lluillui.com/blog/post/skincare-acids-guide/
[4] How to layer acids in your skincare routine explained - Sublime Life sublimelife.in/blogs/sublime-stories/how-to-layer-acids-to-get-maximum-results
[5] Hydroxy Acids, the Most Widely Used Anti-aging Agents - PMC - NCBI www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3941867/
In summary, these ingredients offer a range of benefits for the skin, from hydration and anti-aging to acne treatment and brightening. The best approach is to identify your specific skin concerns and incorporate the most suitable ingredients into your routine.[1][2][3][4][5]
Citations:
[1] www.stubbleandstache.com/blogs/blog/niacinamide-vs-hyaluronic-acid-the-ultimate-skincare-showdown
[2] www.womanandhome.com/beauty/skincare/niacinamide-vs-hyaluronic-acid/
[3] skinkraft.com/blogs/articles/niacinamide-vs-hyaluronic-acid
[4] myeclatshop.com/blogs/the-eclat-edit/niacinamide-vs-hyaluronic-acid
[5] skinq.com/blogs/skincare/niacinamide-vs-hyaluronic-acid-benefits-which-one-should-you-use
How to apply serum
On Toners
No, toning is not necessary for skin health. Toners were originally developed to remove soap scum from the face when lye-based soaps combined with hard water left a sticky residue post cleansing. The alcohol-based toner removed the soap scum eliminating irritation and contributing to cleanser mildness.
On eye creams
Help the look of fine lines and wrinkles.According to the Journal of Cosmetic Dermatology, there are multiple studies supporting eye creams as an effective method for enhancing the smoothness and appearance of larger wrinkles around the eyes.
eye creams ‚Äúmay not be necessary for everyone,‚Äù but she recommends it for those ‚Äúwho are concerned about their undereye area or who are noticing changes in the undereye area.‚Äù
Unlike regular moisturizers, eye creams are formulated to be lightweight and easily absorbed, preventing milia or oil buildup in the sensitive eye region.
Such a cream likely contains a higher concentration of active ingredients designed to combat fine lines. It‚Äôs worth noting the irony that eye creams, although often pricier than facial moisturizers, may have a more specialized formulation that is gentler on the delicate skin around the eyes.
The Takeaway. Eye cream is an effective addition to your skincare routine, especially if you have specific under-eye issues that you‚Äôre hoping to correct. But, if you‚Äôre simply looking to hydrate the eye area and don‚Äôt suffer from dark circles, puffiness, or wrinkles, you can absolutely use your go-to moisturizer.

articles/project-notes/How-to-build-a-wa.title: How to build a wardrobe
articles/project-notes/How-to-build-a-wa.content:
Guide to Building a Versatile Wardrobe
Building a wardrobe requires thoughtful selection of materials, styles, and brands. Here‚Äôs a comprehensive guide to curate a wardrobe that is timeless, functional, and sustainable.

Fabric Selection:
Base Layers

Opt for breathable fabrics like cotton, hemp, bamboo, ramie, linen, or Tencel for items that touch your skin directly and for everyday wear.

Summer Wear

Focus on linen for its breathability but ensure it‚Äôs not see-through. Silk shirts, especially 100% mulberry silk with textures like knitted or hammered, are easy to wear.
Select silk garments, especially 100% mulberry silk, for luxurious texture.

Winter Wear

Choose wool and cashmere blends for warmth and luxury but without excessive polyester content.
For winter coats, avoid polyester content above 20% unless it‚Äôs blended with alpaca or cashmere (up to 30%).
Polyester content above 50% can lead to pilling and poor insulation.
Wool and cashmere blends provide warmth, luxury, and a less flashy appearance at a lower cost.
Linen and silk offer a silky-smooth, durable, and breathable option.
Cotton and linen are a more affordable yet still breathable combination.

Denim

Opt for 100% cotton jeans over blended materials for durability and comfort.

Cashmere

Look for Grade A, B, or C cashmere for warmth and quality. Cashmere is warmer than wool and easier to wash. Look for Grade A, B, or C cashmere based on fibre length and ply. Good cashmere should be soft and resistant to pilling.
Steer clear of cashmere and polyester blends, as they can compromise the quality and performance of the cashmere.

Brands to Consider:

Arket
COS
Massimo Dutti
Boulder Skins
All Saints

Key Pieces for All Seasons:

Tops:

Cotton or silk shirts for summer.
Silk shirts for a luxurious touch.
Fitted t-shirts and high-quality sweaters (wool or cashmere) for layering.


Bottoms:

Jeans: Opt for 100% cotton over blends.
Chinos: Versatile and comfortable.
Linen pants or shorts for summer.


Outerwear:

Tailored wool coats for winter.
Invest in a structured blazer for formal occasions.


Footwear:

Loafers, oxfords, or white leather sneakers for versatility.
Birkenstocks for casual comfort.



Shopping Tips:

Thrifting: Wear simple clothes for easy changing. Carry a tie to check against shirts and have socks on to try shoes.
Measurements: Keep your measurements handy for accurate fitting.
Quality Check: Inspect buttons, buttonholes, and fabric tags for durability and quality.

Styling Rules:

Neutral Palette: Stick to timeless colors like brown, beige, black, charcoal, white, and navy.
Fit: Avoid extremes like skinny or baggy fits. Aim for tailored or slim fits.
Materials: Embrace natural fabrics like linen, wool, leather, cashmere, and cotton for durability and comfort.

Additional Tips:

Investment Pieces: Prioritize quality over quantity, especially with essential items like coats, suits, and shoes.
No Logos: Embrace a minimalist aesthetic without visible branding.
Mix & Match: Opt for versatile pieces that can be dressed up or down for various occasions.

Building a Summer Wardrobe:

Vests/Tank Tops: Both free and fitted options for layering.
Basic T-Shirts: Various colors in cotton or similar fabrics.
Linen Shirts: Long and short-sleeved options for breathability.
Shorts and Pants: Linen or cotton options with adjustable fits.

Wardrobe Basics:

Footwear: Ensure you have a range of comfortable yet stylish shoes.
Tailored Blazer: Navy or grey for formal or smart-casual occasions.

articles/project-notes/Meal-ideas-738eea.title: Meal ideas 738eea10f8094610b58d4b6d05bb9f8d
articles/project-notes/Meal-ideas-738eea.content:
Meal ideas
Mediterranean diet
Creating a week-long meal plan based on the Mediterranean diet can provide a variety of delicious and nutritious meals that prioritize whole foods, healthy fats, lean proteins, and plenty of fruits and vegetables. Here‚Äôs a sample meal plan for one week:
Day 1:

Breakfast: Greek yogurt topped with mixed berries and a drizzle of honey, served with whole grain toast.
Lunch: Mediterranean chickpea salad with cherry tomatoes, cucumber, red onion, feta cheese, olives, and a lemon-olive oil dressing.
Dinner: Grilled lemon-herb salmon served with quinoa pilaf and steamed broccoli.

Day 2:

Breakfast: Oatmeal made with rolled oats, chopped nuts, sliced banana, and a spoonful of almond butter.
Lunch: Whole wheat wrap filled with grilled chicken breast, hummus, mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, and sliced avocado.
Dinner: Whole grain pasta primavera with saut√©ed seasonal vegetables (zucchini, bell peppers, mushrooms) in a garlic-olive oil sauce, topped with grated Parmesan cheese.

Day 3:

Breakfast: Vegetable omelet made with eggs, spinach, tomatoes, and feta cheese, served with whole grain toast.
Lunch: Quinoa and black bean salad with diced bell peppers, corn, cilantro, avocado, and a lime-cumin dressing.
Dinner: Baked Mediterranean chicken thighs with roasted sweet potatoes and a side salad dressed with balsamic vinaigrette.

Day 4:

Breakfast: Greek yogurt parfait layered with sliced peaches, granola, and a sprinkle of cinnamon.
Lunch: Lentil soup made with vegetables, tomatoes, and herbs, served with a side of whole grain bread.
Dinner: Grilled shrimp skewers marinated in olive oil, garlic, and herbs, served with quinoa tabbouleh and grilled asparagus.

Day 5:

Breakfast: Smoothie bowl topped with mixed berries, sliced kiwi, shredded coconut, and a sprinkle of chia seeds.
Lunch: Stuffed bell peppers filled with a mixture of quinoa, ground turkey (or lentils for vegetarian option), diced tomatoes, and herbs.
Dinner: Baked white fish (such as cod or tilapia) with a Mediterranean tomato and olive relish, served with couscous and roasted Brussels sprouts.

Day 6:

Breakfast: Whole grain toast topped with mashed avocado and poached eggs, seasoned with salt, pepper, and red pepper flakes.
Lunch: Greek salad with romaine lettuce, cherry tomatoes, cucumbers, red onions, Kalamata olives, and feta cheese, dressed with olive oil and red wine vinegar.
Dinner: Mediterranean-style stuffed eggplant with a filling of quinoa, pine nuts, raisins, and herbs, served with a side of steamed green beans.

Day 7:

Breakfast: Whole grain pancakes topped with fresh berries and a dollop of Greek yogurt.
Lunch: Hummus platter with whole grain pita bread, sliced vegetables (carrots, bell peppers, celery), and marinated olives.
Dinner: Herb-roasted chicken breast with roasted potatoes and a side salad of mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, and cucumber, dressed with lemon-olive oil vinaigrette.

Snack Options (for each day):

Mixed nuts (almonds, walnuts, pistachios)
Sliced apple or pear with almond butter
Raw vegetable sticks (carrots, celery) with tzatziki dip
Greek yogurt with honey and nuts
Fresh fruit (berries, grapes) with a small piece of cheese

Adjust portion sizes and ingredients based on individual preferences and dietary needs. This meal plan provides a good balance of nutrients and flavors typical of the Mediterranean diet, focusing on whole, minimally processed foods, and healthy cooking methods like grilling, baking, and saut√©ing with olive oil. Remember to stay hydrated with water throughout the day and enjoy meals mindfully to fully savor the flavors and benefits of this wholesome eating approach.
High Protein
Certainly! Here‚Äôs a 1-week meal plan for a high-protein diet with plenty of fiber, avoiding unhealthy ingredients like processed foods, sugar, high-fructose corn syrup, refined carbohydrates, trans fats, excessive sodium, artificial sweeteners, and processed meats:
Day 1:

Breakfast: Scrambled eggs with spinach and tomatoes, served with a slice of whole grain toast.
Lunch: Grilled chicken salad with mixed greens, bell peppers, cucumber, chickpeas, and a lemon-herb vinaigrette.
Dinner: Baked salmon with quinoa pilaf and steamed broccoli.

Day 2:

Breakfast: Greek yogurt parfait with sliced almonds, chia seeds, and fresh berries.
Lunch: Turkey and avocado wrap with whole grain tortilla, lettuce, and tomato.
Dinner: Lentil and vegetable stew served with a side of roasted Brussels sprouts.

Day 3:

Breakfast: Protein smoothie made with unsweetened almond milk, protein powder, spinach, and a tablespoon of almond butter.
Lunch: Quinoa salad with black beans, corn, diced bell peppers, cherry tomatoes, and cilantro-lime dressing.
Dinner: Grilled tofu stir-fry with broccoli, bell peppers, snap peas, and a low-sodium soy sauce.

Day 4:

Breakfast: Overnight oats prepared with rolled oats, almond milk, Greek yogurt, sliced banana, and walnuts.
Lunch: Chickpea and vegetable curry served over brown rice.
Dinner: Baked chicken breast with roasted sweet potatoes and a side of saut√©ed kale.

Day 5:

Breakfast: Scrambled eggs with mushrooms and onions, served with whole grain toast.
Lunch: Spinach and feta stuffed bell peppers, served with a side salad of mixed greens.
Dinner: Grilled shrimp skewers with quinoa tabbouleh and roasted asparagus.

Day 6:

Breakfast: Cottage cheese topped with sliced peaches and a sprinkle of flaxseeds.
Lunch: Turkey chili made with lean ground turkey, kidney beans, diced tomatoes, and spices.
Dinner: Baked cod fillets with lemon-garlic butter sauce, served with quinoa and steamed green beans.

Day 7:

Breakfast: Whole grain protein pancakes topped with Greek yogurt and mixed berries.
Lunch: Zucchini noodles (zoodles) with grilled chicken and homemade pesto sauce.
Dinner: Lentil and kale salad with roasted butternut squash, pumpkin seeds, and a lemon-tahini dressing.

Snack Options (for each day):

Mixed nuts (almonds, walnuts, pistachios)
Sliced bell peppers and hummus
Greek yogurt with sliced almonds and cinnamon
Hard-boiled eggs
Fresh fruit (apples, oranges) with a small piece of cheese

This meal plan emphasizes whole, unprocessed foods that are rich in protein and fiber, providing essential nutrients while avoiding unhealthy ingredients. Feel free to adjust portion sizes and ingredients based on individual preferences and dietary needs. Staying hydrated with water throughout the day is also important for overall health. Enjoy these nutritious and satisfying meals!

articles/project-notes/On-a-shared-histo.content:
On a shared history
Year 1
I am Ovid Shelley, Keates I know all there is to know about love I have felt its pain, it‚Äôs ache
I am Blake Byron, Shakespeare himself I have written love Spoken it to life from nothing
I knew you
Year One
I know all there is to know about love I have written it And I have read it I have felt it, Given so much of it that I thought I would never lose it And I have lost it
I am Ovidius Heart sage. Guru And I love you
Month one
You are the sea Vast and salty You have always been Since the day we met by the beach
You are the sea Vast and salty Stinging my every wound As I lose myself in you
You are the sea Vast and salty I am freshwater fish Drowning  Day One
I have not known love till I met you Not books not poems Not words and not songs Could have prepared me
I do not know love Till every morning when I wake up to your face Till every night that I cannot fall asleep Without you next to me
I may not know what love is But tell me how to love you today And I will love you each day

articles/project-notes/On-inspiring-team.filePath: articles/project-notes/On inspiring teammates during change - Memo 1ec13a6712254c4687fbdb59ede167bb.md
articles/project-notes/On-inspiring-team.title: On inspiring teammates during change - Memo 1ec13a6712254c4687fbdb59ede167bb
articles/project-notes/On-inspiring-team.content:
On inspiring teammates during change - Memo
Source fleeting notes
Idea summary
Exploration
I know I call it a Project a lot, but what it really is, is a business
Businesses create value. For them to continue to exist, they must continue to create vlue And for that to happen, we, the people that mke up the business must continue to create value That is how we serve the business so that it too can serve us
People and businesses fall out with each other because they do not believe there is an equivalent exchange of value Whether the work is not stimulating enough, or the pay is not rewarding enough Even friendships are built on value exchange. If a friend does not serve you, it strains the relationship
Given the events of the past few weeks, I believe that ach and everyone of us wants to be here. That is why we are here And based on that belief, I believe that we are entering into ever conversation, every agreement, in good faith that we are looking to deliver the best that we can. That we all want to create value. For ourselves and for the business And to continue to be here, we must align our goals with those of the business
But the responsibility does not stop there. Because we also have a responsibility to each other. Assume that the other person is giving their best to their work, and respond in kind by giving your best too. Not just the best that you think you personally can, but the best that the team deserves if you want it to be great
You are the core development team of a startup business. You are building this business with your own hands line by line
If perhaps you don‚Äôt have faith in the business, consider that without working product, we have customers that literally go through the hassle of manually using the product. That shows that there is. real need. There are people that want what you are building.
If it fails, we have all failed. It means that we have not created value On our resumes, we will have a failed product
I do not like to fail
How do we ensure that we do not fail We have a plan, we need to execute that plan
