articles/tope-arebi/On-Social-Skins-e0f3.title: On Social Skins e0f39785bbe7448d9891560414bc26e1
articles/tope-arebi/On-Social-Skins-e0f3.content:
On Social Skins
Source fleeting notes

Social skins

Idea summary
Exploration
For most of human existence, the act of going out into the world and interacting socially was for survival. Which mean the optimal social persona had to be shaped around the true self by making countless mini adaptations to ensure survival. In solitude, you could shed off the social shell to unearth your true self. To revert. Nowaday, social life is everywhere. Constantly in the palm of our hands. So we never have time to drop the shell. To be our real selves. Always constantly making tiny adaptations to push all the right social markers forward. Likes, followers, status, job title.
Most interestingly, digital social spaces responsible for this contortion of the self advocate that the recipe for platform success includes some sort of ‚Äúauthenticity‚Äù or ‚Äúoriginality‚Äù. But what even is that? Who are you when you not micro-adapting your social skin for relevance or survival. Have you met you?
Relatable content is touted to be the most successful type of content. ‚ÄúIf you post about how you feel, others will follow you because they feel it too‚Äù. But is this not the first crack in the glass ceiling. When you are at your most authentic, you will equally be the most relatable. Because you will be just like everybody.
This micro-adapted skin suit is self-evident when we consider behaviour in the context of different social environment. We can emphasise or suppress certain qualities of our personality depending on the social context within which we find ourselves. We can be more nurturing with family, more brash at work, more patient with parents.
What we end up with is a collection of multiple social shells which we can switch into or deploy depending on the social context.
The question then is, is the true self the amalgamation of all these selves, or is it what remains when we strip them all away.
Idea context
Robert Greene‚Äôs interview with Diary of a CEO on power and seduction in which he quotes the idea of the public self as a role to be played in social gatherings, and a mask to be shed once one arrives home. An idea that was quite commonplace pre social media and smartphones. 70s 80s?

On being more by doing more
Source fleeting notes
Idea summary
Exploration
There are not many things that I want out of life. Not money, not God. Not always love. For the better part of my life, world peace was the only thing I ever prayed for. More specifically, for every person in the world to have enough or be enough to experience the feeling of contentment. I don‚Äôt think that this was the result of being good natured. I simply pity people because humanity is such a fragile and foolish species. Nonetheless, that is my selfless dream.
My selfish dream is to learn everything. To put it in more cliche terms, ‚Äúto be better today than I was yesterday.‚Äù
I can be no good to anybody if I am no good at anything meditations

articles/tope-arebi/On-forgiveness-and-m.content:
On forgiveness and mercy
Source fleeting notes
Idea summary
Exploration
What are the rules of forgiveness? How do we decide who is worthy of forgiveness and who is not? When do we say, ‚ÄúI believe this person has learnt from their mistakes?‚Äù
This question is doubly interesting because of a real incident on twitter.
Korty found forgiveness had to come by after falling afoul of the crowd despite apologising in the space of a day
Waspapping, a serial offender and ‚Äúethnic bigot‚Äù found forgiveness after asking for donations to free his kidnapped brother
Is the gravity of the crime a factor? If human morality is a line perhaps we can tolerate slight deviations but we are more eager to pull back to the fold larger off-shoots Gravity and forgiveness
Another factor may be gender. Are women held to higher standards and thus less likely to be forgiven when they err. Gender and forgiveness
Recency bias may possibly be another. If we are inundated with a particular brand of malevolence over an extended period of time, do we become desensitised to its effect on us, and thus more likely to forgive Exposure bias and forgiveness
Why do people make excuses for the coorrupt political class. Are they used to it and more willing to forgive former corrupt leaders due to exposure link
Cancel culture. Where does it come from? Is it effective? Or are the potential effects of our actions simply magnified by loudness of social media
Article idea for Thoughtfood

articles/tope-arebi/On-making-a-case-for.title: On making a case for Atheism 1f2635c581e080edbd0ec64a47b1af4b
articles/tope-arebi/On-making-a-case-for.content:
On making a case for Atheism
Source fleeting notes
Idea summary
Exploration
First of all, I want to establish that I do not like labels. No matter how may times a word is described in a book of definitions, the meaning of a word will always be contextual. That is simply the nature of human society. Words are simply a tool for communicating, and so our interpretation of them is always inferred from the situation in which they are used. They can be purpose fit. This is why we can understand what words mean even when we have not heard them used before. But in the situation, we can understand their intent. And it does not matter what an Oxford or Longman has to say about it. They can only catch up.
The word Atheism is a label as well. And contextually, it has come to mean a person who fervently rejects the idea that there there is a God. I can understand this vehemence from previous religious adherents who, upon realising they have been conned, lash out for having been taken from a fool. However, the definition of atheism has more broad connotations than this.
Atheism is an absence of belief in the existence of deities. While the rejection of belief in deities and the belief that there are no deities are also implicit in this, they are subset of a much broader worldview. But just as we all experience life in an almost infinite number of ways, our relationship with the divine can manifest in as many ways as well.
These days, when asked what my religion is, which is often given the origin of my name, the atheist label is the only one available to me given my limited options. But my relationship with the divine is so much more than that.
Sadghuru says ‚ÄúDo not empower someone who has a limited sense of identity. That is‚Äù

articles/tope-arebi/Progressive-Overload.title: Progressive Overload 1f2635c581e0809c9532f732e7f3feec
articles/tope-arebi/Progressive-Overload.content:
Progressive Overload
To get stronger at the gym, you need to  increase the demand or strain you place on your body over time. Even if you‚Äôre not aware of the concept of progressive overload, you naturally do this by lifting what you can at a certain point in time, and increasing it over time as your body adapts to the tasks you are giving it.
There are generally 4 ways to do this

increase weight
increase reps
reduce rest
vary leverage

What is common here is that you are doing more of the thing that you are trying to be better at.
The same thing  applies to pretty much every other area of life. The same ability that drove our adaptations as a species, will help you learn that new skill.
Just get those reps in. And remember to rest adequately.
(work table, gym clips)

articles/tope-arebi/Salford/The-importan.title: The importance of documentation
articles/tope-arebi/Salford/The-importan.content:
Core Takeaway Message: Personal process documentation is important, it is easy, and if we start now, the benefits will be immense. Target Audience: Members of the department of digital IT at the University of Salford. Approximate Duration: 30 minutes Tone: Engaging, storytelling-focused, practical, forward-looking.
Slide 1: Title Slide


Slide Title: Unlocking Our Collective Expertise: The Power of Personal Process Notes & AI-Driven Insights


Key Content Points:


[Your Name]


Digital IT Department, University of Salford


[Date of Presentation]




Detailed Speaker Notes:


(Start with a welcoming and confident tone) ‚ÄúGood morning/afternoon, everyone. Thank you for being here today.‚Äù


‚ÄúMy name is [Your Name], and I‚Äôm excited to share some thoughts on a topic I believe holds significant potential for us all: ‚ÄòUnlocking Our Collective Expertise‚Äô.‚Äù


‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be looking at the power of personal process notes and how, eventually, we could even leverage AI to gain further insights.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A clean, professional background. Perhaps an abstract image representing interconnectedness, knowledge, or a subtle University of Salford branding element if appropriate. A stylised key unlocking a network or brain icon.



Slide 2: Introduction & Our Journey Today


Slide Title: Why We‚Äôre Here & What We‚Äôll Explore


Key Content Points:


A fresh look at ‚Äúdocumentation.‚Äù


The untapped power of our individual knowledge.


Immediate wins for individuals, teams, and the department.


A vision for future, AI-enhanced insights.


Your role in shaping this.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


(Engaging hook) ‚ÄúHow many of us have ever thought, ‚ÄòIf only I knew how they did that,‚Äô or ‚ÄòI wish I‚Äôd written down how I solved that tricky issue last time‚Äô?‚Äù


‚ÄúToday, I want us to take a fresh look at ‚Äòdocumentation‚Äô ‚Äì not as a chore, but as a powerful tool. We‚Äôll explore the often-untapped power of our individual, everyday process knowledge.‚Äù


‚ÄúWe‚Äôll discuss the immediate, tangible benefits this can bring ‚Äì for our own efficiency, for smoother handovers, for easier onboarding, and for preserving critical know-how within our department.‚Äù


‚ÄúThen, we‚Äôll look a little further ahead at an exciting vision: how we might one day use AI to amplify these benefits, helping us make smarter strategic decisions and further streamline how we work.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd most importantly, I want to discuss how each of you can play a part in this, starting with some very simple steps.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A roadmap or journey graphic with icons representing the key agenda points. Or a lightbulb icon turning on, symbolising new perspectives.



Slide 3: A Little About Me & My Passion for This


Slide Title: My Journey to This Idea


Key Content Points:


Relatively new to the Digital IT team ‚Äì excited to contribute!


A lifelong ‚Äúnote-taker‚Äù (ask my childhood self about lists!).


Academic background: 2 Master‚Äôs degrees, 3 research papers.


Relevant research: ‚ÄúAI-Driven Knowledge Management Systems.‚Äù




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúBefore we dive deeper, and as I‚Äôm still getting to know many of you, perhaps a very brief word on why this subject is particularly close to my heart.‚Äù


‚ÄúI‚Äôm [Your Name], and I‚Äôm relatively new to our fantastic Digital IT team here at Salford, but I‚Äôm incredibly keen to contribute and learn from you all.‚Äù


‚ÄúYou could say my interest in organising information started young ‚Äì I was definitely that child who obsessively made lists for just about everything! Some habits stick, I suppose!‚Äù


‚ÄúMore formally, my academic journey, which includes two Master‚Äôs degrees, has allowed me to delve deeply into how organisations learn, manage information, and innovate. This led to several research papers, including one specifically titled ‚ÄòAI-Driven Knowledge Management Systems‚Äô.‚Äù


‚ÄúSo, exploring how we can better capture, share, and leverage knowledge, especially with emerging technologies, isn‚Äôt just a professional interest; it‚Äôs something I‚Äôm genuinely passionate about. And I believe there‚Äôs a real, practical opportunity for us here.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A simple, friendly photo of yourself (optional). Or, icons representing education (graduation cap), research (magnifying glass/document), and perhaps a subtle, stylised ‚ÄúAI brain‚Äù or network icon.



Slide 4: The Knowledge Around Us: Explicit vs. Tacit


Slide Title: Understanding Our Knowledge Landscape


Key Content Points:


Explicit Knowledge: Codified, documented (manuals, official guides). The ‚ÄúKnow-What.‚Äù


Tacit Knowledge: Experiential, intuitive, hard to articulate. The ‚ÄúKnow-How.‚Äù


Our official notes are great for explicit knowledge.


But what about the ‚Äúsecret sauce‚Äù ‚Äì our collective tacit wisdom?




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúTo understand the opportunity before us, it‚Äôs helpful to distinguish between two fundamental types of knowledge within any organisation, including ours.‚Äù


‚ÄúFirst, there‚Äôs Explicit Knowledge. This is the knowledge that‚Äôs easily articulated, written down, codified, and shared. Think of our official departmental procedures, our system manuals, our shared knowledge base articles. It‚Äôs the essential ‚Äòknow-what‚Äô.‚Äù


‚ÄúThen, there‚Äôs Tacit Knowledge. This is far more personal, deeply rooted in individual experience, intuition, and context. It‚Äôs the practical skills, the ‚Äòtricks of the trade‚Äô, the ‚Äògut feelings‚Äô about how to solve a novel problem, the efficient shortcuts we discover. It‚Äôs the invaluable ‚Äòknow-how‚Äô.‚Äù


‚ÄúOur current departmental notes do an excellent job capturing explicit knowledge, and that‚Äôs vital.‚Äù


‚ÄúBut my question today is: how effectively are we capturing and sharing that vast reservoir of tacit wisdom ‚Äì the ‚Äòsecret sauce‚Äô that each of you brings to your roles every day?‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A two-part diagram. One side an open book or document icon (Explicit), the other a silhouette of a head with gears or a lightbulb inside (Tacit). Arrows showing current systems capture explicit well, but tacit is often uncaptured.



Slide 5: The Reality of Uncaptured Know-How (Interactive)


Slide Title: Ever Felt This? The Power of ‚ÄúUnwritten Rules‚Äù


Key Content Points:


Quick show of hands:


Faced a tricky, ‚Äúoff-script‚Äù task recently?


Possess unique solutions/shortcuts not in official guides?




This gap is where opportunity lies.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúLet‚Äôs make this concept of uncaptured tacit knowledge a bit more concrete with a quick interactive moment.‚Äù


‚ÄúBy a quick show of hands ‚Äì and please be honest! ‚Äì how many of us, perhaps in the last month or so, have found ourselves tackling a task that was a bit ‚Äòoff-script‚Äô from the standard procedure, and it gave you a bit more trouble or took longer than expected simply because you didn‚Äôt have that one specific piece of insight or prior experience? (Pause, observe hands, acknowledge).‚Äù


‚ÄúOkay, quite a few of us. Now, another quick show of hands: how many of us have developed our own specific, hard-earned experience, a useful ‚Äòtrick‚Äô, or a shortcut for some of our regular tasks that isn‚Äôt written down in any official guide, but you know it saves time or solves a common problem effectively? (Pause, observe hands, acknowledge).‚Äù


‚ÄúThank you. That gap ‚Äì between the challenges many of us just acknowledged facing, and the undocumented solutions and efficiencies that others possess ‚Äì is precisely where personal process documentation can make a real, immediate difference. It‚Äôs about connecting those dots.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

Two simple, large question mark icons or thought bubble icons. Or silhouettes of people with raised hands. Keep it clean and focused on the audience‚Äôs participation.



Slide 6: Introducing: Personal Process Documentation


Slide Title: Personal Process Notes: Your Know-How, Documented


Key Content Points:


Concise notes on how you execute specific tasks.


Not novels, but practical, actionable guides for you (and potentially colleagues).


Strategic Focus (Not ‚ÄúDocument Everything!‚Äú):


Critical/High-Impact tasks (projects, goals).


Complex or Infrequently Performed procedures.


Tasks with ‚ÄúGotchas‚Äù or common pitfalls.


Likely for handover/delegation.






Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúSo, what‚Äôs the first step in bridging this gap? I propose something straightforward: Personal Process Documentation.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis is simply about each of us taking concise, practical notes on how we execute our specific tasks and projects. Think step-by-step guides for recurring tasks unique to your workflow, checklists for complex procedures, notes on troubleshooting common issues you encounter, or key contacts for specific parts of a process.‚Äù


‚ÄúCrucially, this isn‚Äôt about writing novels or creating burdensome new official documents. It‚Äôs about creating practical, actionable notes primarily for your own benefit, which can then easily benefit others.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd I want to be absolutely clear: this isn‚Äôt about trying to document every single micro-action we take. That would be overwhelming and counterproductive. The key is to be strategic and focus our efforts. We should prioritise documenting processes or tasks that are:‚Äù


‚ÄúFirstly, Critical or High-Impact ‚Äì those directly tied to key projects, our individual performance goals, or core departmental objectives.‚Äù


‚ÄúSecondly, Complex or Infrequently Performed procedures ‚Äì where details are easily forgotten between instances.‚Äù


‚ÄúThirdly, tasks known to have ‚ÄòGotchas‚Äô or common pitfalls not covered in official guides.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd finally, tasks you anticipate needing to pass on or explain to others in the future.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about targeted documentation that delivers the most value for the effort involved.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

An icon of a notebook and pen, or a stylised checklist. Bullet points on the slide could have small, relevant icons (e.g., target for critical, brain for complex, warning sign for gotchas, people icon for handover).



Slide 7: The Immediate Wins: For You, The Individual


Slide Title: What‚Äôs In It For You? (Starting Today!)


Key Content Points:


Enhanced personal efficiency & clarity.


Reduced cognitive load (less to remember!).


Easier to pick up tasks after a break.


Consistency in your own work.


A foundation for self-reflection & improvement.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúLet‚Äôs talk about the immediate, tangible benefits of this simple practice, starting with what‚Äôs in it for you as an individual.‚Äù


‚ÄúFirstly, it brings enhanced personal efficiency and clarity. Documenting your process forces you to think it through, often revealing simpler or better ways to do things.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt reduces your cognitive load. You don‚Äôt have to keep every intricate step of every process in your head. Your notes become your external brain.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis makes it much easier to pick up tasks after a break, whether that‚Äôs a holiday or just switching between different projects. You can get back up to speed much faster.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt promotes consistency in your own work, ensuring you don‚Äôt miss crucial steps, especially for tasks you don‚Äôt do every day.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd finally, the very act of documenting can be a powerful tool for self-reflection and identifying areas for your own process improvement.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

An icon of a person with a lightbulb above their head, or a smoothly turning gear. Focus on individual empowerment.



Slide 8: The Immediate Wins: Smoother Handovers & Onboarding


Slide Title: Powering Up Our Team: Handovers & Onboarding


Key Content Points:


Dramatically smoother handovers (holidays, role changes).


Reduced burden on colleagues taking over.


Faster, more effective onboarding for new hires/internal moves.


Captures the ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù beyond official manuals.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúThe individual benefits are compelling, but the positive impact quickly extends to our colleagues and the wider team, especially when it comes to handovers and onboarding.‚Äù


‚ÄúImagine how much smoother handovers could be ‚Äì whether someone is going on annual leave, moving to a new role within the department, or even leaving the university. Their personal process notes provide an invaluable head-start for the person stepping in.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis significantly reduces the burden and stress on colleagues taking over tasks, allowing them to become productive much faster.‚Äù


‚ÄúFor new hires, or for existing staff moving into new roles within Digital IT, these notes can make their onboarding experience dramatically faster and more effective. They get access not just to the official manuals, but to the practical, day-to-day ‚Äòhow-to‚Äô from experienced team members.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis is about capturing that crucial operational wisdom that often lives only in people‚Äôs heads.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

Two figures shaking hands or passing a baton. Or a ‚Äúwelcome‚Äù sign with an arrow showing an upward trajectory (faster onboarding). Icons representing different roles in IT (BA, Dev, Service Desk) connecting.



Slide 9: The Immediate Wins: Safeguarding Our ‚ÄúGenerational Knowledge‚Äù


Slide Title: Protecting Our ‚ÄúSecret Sauce‚Äù: The Knowledge Cliff


Key Content Points:


Many organisations have long-serving, deeply knowledgeable staff.


Risk: ‚ÄúGenerational Knowledge Cliff‚Äù if many depart around the same time.


Losing invaluable, hyperspecific ‚Äúsecret sauce.‚Äù


Personal documentation now helps retain this vital experience.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúThere‚Äôs another critical, immediate benefit, especially relevant for established organisations like ours that are fortunate to have many dedicated, long-term staff.‚Äù


‚ÄúOver many years, invaluable, often highly specific operational knowledge ‚Äì what we might call the ‚Äòsecret sauce‚Äô that keeps things running optimally ‚Äì naturally becomes concentrated with our most experienced colleagues.‚Äù


‚ÄúA common pattern we observe is that these groups of long-serving staff, having shared similar career journeys, may also approach significant milestones, like retirement, within a similar general timeframe. This isn‚Äôt a criticism; it‚Äôs a natural lifecycle.‚Äù


‚ÄúThe risk, however, is what we could term a ‚ÄòGenerational Knowledge Cliff.‚Äô If several key individuals with this deep, tacit knowledge depart concurrently, the department can face a sudden and substantial loss of critical operational wisdom, creating a knowledge vacuum that‚Äôs incredibly hard to fill quickly.‚Äù


‚ÄúBy actively promoting and creating personal process documentation now, we provide a vital mechanism to capture and retain this invaluable, often unwritten, experience before it walks out the door. This safeguards our operational continuity and our collective know-how for the future.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

An image of a vault or a treasure chest, symbolising valuable knowledge. Or a graph showing a ‚Äúcliff edge‚Äù with an arrow showing documentation as a safety net.



Slide 10: The Immediate Wins: Team & Departmental Effectiveness


Slide Title: Stronger Together: Department-Wide Gains


Key Content Points:


Improved collaboration (understanding each other‚Äôs workflows).


Excellent resource for informal cross-training.


Organic emergence of best practices.


Potential for reduced errors and greater consistency.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúThe ripple effects continue, boosting overall team and departmental effectiveness.‚Äù


‚ÄúWhen individuals document their processes, it fosters improved collaboration. It becomes easier to understand how colleagues approach related tasks, leading to better integration of efforts.‚Äù


‚ÄúThese notes become an excellent resource for informal cross-training. Team members can more easily learn aspects of each other‚Äôs roles, increasing our collective resilience and flexibility.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis can lead to the organic emergence and adoption of best practices. As people share their efficient methods, others can learn from them, naturally raising the bar for the whole department.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd ultimately, clearer, documented processes have the potential to lead to reduced errors and greater consistency in how we deliver our services and projects.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A group of diverse people working together, or interconnected gears working smoothly. Icons representing different IT functions (analysis, development, support, delivery) linked together.



Slide 11: Summary of Immediate Gains ‚Äì The Power in Our Hands Today!


Slide Title: The Value Proposition: Clear & Present Benefits


Key Content Points:


All these benefits are achievable NOW.


Increased personal efficiency.


Seamless handovers & faster onboarding.


Safeguarded critical experience.


Enhanced team collaboration & consistency.


No complex systems needed to start. Just commitment.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúSo, to be absolutely clear, and this is a crucial point: every benefit we‚Äôve just covered ‚Äì the increased personal efficiency, the seamless handovers, the faster onboarding, the safeguarding of critical experience, and the enhanced team collaboration ‚Äì these are all significant, tangible advantages we can start realising right now.‚Äù


‚ÄúThese gains are achievable simply by each of us committing to the straightforward practice of creating and maintaining our own personal process documentation. No complex systems, no lengthy development times, no major budget approvals are required for these foundational improvements.‚Äù


‚ÄúThe power to make these positive changes, to improve how we work individually and collectively, is literally in our hands today. It starts with a simple decision to capture our know-how.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A bold, impactful slide. Perhaps a large green tick mark next to ‚ÄúBenefits NOW!‚Äù or a hand holding a glowing lightbulb. Use strong, clear typography.



Slide 12: The Future Amplified: AI-Powered Knowledge Leverage


Slide Title: Looking Ahead: What If We Could Amplify This?


Key Content Points:


Building on our documented knowledge foundation.


Imagine an AI that understands our collective experience.


Not just search, but insight generation.


This is a future vision, a potential evolution.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúNow, having established the immediate and substantial value of capturing and manually accessing our individualised knowledge, let‚Äôs explore an exciting future possibility. This is about building on that strong foundation.‚Äù


‚ÄúWhat if we could then take this already powerful asset of documented personal processes and elevate its utility even further? Imagine an AI tool, securely trained on our department‚Äôs anonymised collective experience, that could understand the nuances within these notes.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis wouldn‚Äôt just be a simple keyword search. We‚Äôre talking about the potential for genuine insight generation ‚Äì identifying patterns, highlighting challenges, and suggesting optimisations.‚Äù


‚ÄúI want to stress that this is a future vision, a potential evolution of what we start building today. It‚Äôs not something for immediate implementation, but a glimpse of what could be possible.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A slightly futuristic graphic. Perhaps a network of interconnected nodes with an ‚ÄúAI brain‚Äù at the centre, processing information. Or a magnifying glass over data points, revealing patterns.



Slide 13: AI Benefits: Strategic & Managerial Insights


Slide Title: AI for Strategic Advantage: Managerial View


Key Content Points:


Identify systemic challenges & bottlenecks across processes.


Highlight areas for optimisation & standardisation (best practices).


Inform targeted training needs based on collective gaps.


Data-driven decision-making for departmental improvements.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúAt a strategic or managerial level, such an AI tool could offer powerful capabilities.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt could help identify systemic challenges and bottlenecks that might be occurring across multiple individuals‚Äô processes, even if each person only sees their part of the problem.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt could highlight areas for optimisation and standardisation by comparing different approaches to similar tasks documented by various team members, helping us uncover and adopt true best practices.‚Äù


‚ÄúPatterns in the documented experiences could inform targeted training needs, revealing collective gaps in knowledge or skills that we could then address proactively.‚Äù


‚ÄúUltimately, this provides a pathway to more data-driven decision-making for departmental improvements, based on the actual lived experiences of the team.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A dashboard interface mock-up showing analytics or insights. Or a ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù view of interconnected processes with highlighted areas.



Slide 14: AI Benefits: Empowering Individuals & Onboarding


Slide Title: AI for Personal Empowerment: Faster Learning


Key Content Points:


Accelerated, context-aware onboarding for new staff.

‚ÄúHow do I do X for Project Y?‚Äù ‚Üí AI provides curated steps.



‚ÄúJust-in-time‚Äù learning & troubleshooting for all.


Reduces repetitive questions to mentors/seniors.




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúThe benefits wouldn‚Äôt just be managerial; they would also significantly empower individuals, especially new team members.‚Äù


‚ÄúImagine accelerated, context-aware onboarding. A new starter could ask the AI, ‚ÄòHow do I complete the requirements gathering phase for a student portal project?‚Äô and receive step-by-step guidance synthesized from the collective documented experiences of our seasoned Business Analysts, not just a generic manual.‚Äù


‚ÄúFor all of us, it could provide ‚Äòjust-in-time‚Äô learning and troubleshooting support. Stuck on a less frequent task? Ask the AI for a quick reminder or common solutions, drawing on the distilled wisdom of colleagues.‚Äù


‚ÄúThis, in turn, reduces the burden of repetitive questions on mentors and senior staff, freeing them up for more complex challenges.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A new team member confidently navigating a system with AI assistance (e.g., a chat interface). Or a ‚Äúfast forward‚Äù icon applied to a learning curve.



Slide 15: Our Path Forward: Proposal & Call to Action


Slide Title: Starting the Journey: Our Next Steps


Key Content Points:


Short-Term (Let‚Äôs start now!):


Encourage personal process note-taking.


Share simple templates/suggested tools (OneNote, etc.).


Voluntary pilot group to explore & share experiences?




Longer-Term (The AI Vision):


This is a conversation starter.


No immediate implementation plan for AI.


Interested in exploring this further? Let‚Äôs talk! (Form a working group?)






Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúSo, how do we move forward from here?‚Äù


‚ÄúMy short-term proposal is simple and actionable: let‚Äôs start now by simply encouraging and embracing the habit of creating these personal process notes. We could share a few simple templates or suggest preferred tools that many of us already use, like OneNote, or perhaps a dedicated space within our existing knowledge base for these personal drafts.‚Äù


‚ÄúPerhaps we could even form a small, voluntary pilot group to actively try this for a month and then share their experiences and any useful templates they develop.‚Äù


‚ÄúRegarding the longer-term AI integration, I want to reiterate: this is a forward-looking vision. I understand this isn‚Äôt something that can be implemented overnight, and I don‚Äôt have a fully detailed practical implementation plan to present today for that grander vision.‚Äù


‚ÄúMy primary goal with this aspect is to spark a conversation and gauge interest. If this concept of leveraging our collective experience through an intelligent system resonates with you, and particularly if anyone is interested in exploring how we might build towards this, I would be very keen to collaborate. Perhaps we could form a small, informal working group to investigate potential AI tools, consider data privacy, and outline what a future pilot project might involve.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A split slide: one side showing simple tools like a notebook/pen (Short-Term), the other side a more futuristic AI icon (Longer-Term). A ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Talk‚Äù or ‚ÄúJoin the Conversation‚Äù speech bubble.



Slide 16: Core Message & Thank You


Slide Title: Key Takeaway: Easy Start, Immense Benefits


Key Content Points:


Personal process documentation is important.


It‚Äôs easy to start.


The benefits ‚Äì immediate and future ‚Äì are immense.


Let‚Äôs unlock our collective expertise, together.


Thank You! Questions?




Detailed Speaker Notes:


‚ÄúSo, if there are just a few things to take away from our discussion today, it‚Äôs this:‚Äù


‚ÄúPersonal process documentation is incredibly important for individual efficiency, team cohesion, and departmental resilience.‚Äù


‚ÄúIt‚Äôs surprisingly easy to start. Focus on high-value tasks, keep it practical, and use tools you‚Äôre comfortable with.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd finally, the benefits ‚Äì both the immediate ones we can achieve now, and the exciting future potential with AI ‚Äì are truly immense.‚Äù


‚ÄúI genuinely believe that by embracing this, we can unlock our collective expertise and make Digital IT at Salford an even more effective and supportive place to work.‚Äù


‚ÄúThank you very much for your time and attention. I‚Äôd now be happy to answer any questions you might have or hear your thoughts.‚Äù




Visual Suggestion:

A strong, clean design. Perhaps the main presentation title again, or a graphic summarising the core message (e.g., a seed growing into a large tree). University of Salford logo. Contact information if desired.



This detailed draft should provide a solid structure and narrative for your presentation. Remember to rehearse it to get a feel for the timing and to deliver it with genuine enthusiasm! Good luck!

articles/tope-arebi/Social-Skins-Surviva.filePath: articles/tope arebi/Social Skins Survival of the Socially Adept.md
articles/tope-arebi/Social-Skins-Surviva.title: Social Skins Survival of the Socially Adept
articles/tope-arebi/Social-Skins-Surviva.content:
On Social Skins
Bite


x - x
Chew
Intro: Hook. Establish the framework of survival by social skills. Why do we do it, why do we need to?
‚ÄúMan is a social animal‚Äù. ‚ÄúNo man is an island‚Äù. Several commonly used metaphors refer to our inability to extricate man from the act of socially interacting with other humans. This ability is the foundation of our society and civilisation. It is not a stretch to say that our complex social structures are what distinguish us from other animals. The ability to not just be social, but to build systems of cooperation and competition, has helped us master our natural environment. But what is But at what cost (Rewrite this line with a better segue)
Social Evolution / Evolutionary Adaptations for Social Survival
Humans evolved physical adaptations to survive the physical environment in which we exist. At some point in the evolutionary timeline, human intelligence developed to a point where physical prowess was not the sole means for survival. The concept of survival of the fittest gained more dimensions in line with our games of competition and cooperation.  As our social systems grew in complexity, a social environment emerged within which we also needed to survive. And just as with our physical environment, we developed necessary adaptations to navigate this social space.
In this system, through communication, people could lose or gain power, resources and status. The act of socialisation became a test of survival fitness - failure at which could spell disaster. One consequence of this is that it became necessary for individual members of our society to hone a set of skills to navigate this social landscape. Like all optimisations, these skills had to be developed for specific circumstances and be deployable in a wide range of scenarios.
This involves consciously shaping ourselves and the expression of our traits and abilities However, our sense of self, our identity, is constructed through the interactions of our unconscious/subconscious mind and our experiences, usually starting from childhood. Humans thus in the course of their lives learn to maintain two layers of self, an external form that is constantly manipulated and an internal central identity that serves as the foundation for this process.
Jung explains that the development of this ability is a critical part of the journey to adulthood
Sip #1: Tim Urban has a amazing article on just how complex navigating social interactions can be waitbutwhy.com/2014/01/the-great-perils-of-social-interaction.html
The mechanics of social adaptation
This identity fragmentation is self-evident when we consider behaviour in the context of different social environments. We can emphasise or suppress certain qualities of our personality depending on the social context within which we find ourselves. We can be more nurturing with family, more brash at work, and more patient with parents. What we end up with is a collection of multiple social shells which we can switch into or deploy depending on the social context.
Banduras theory
Jung‚Äôs theory
Sip #2: Jung explains this phenomenon as a persona or mask that a person wears in social interactions to conceal their true nature. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persona_(psychology)
Digital Social Spaces and Authenticity
Digital social spaces
Of course, today‚Äôs economy and given the general advancement of our ways of life, nothing is so critical anymore. While loss of social status is not necessarily survival related, it can be just as crippling. It may even be a thing of pride that human society is now so structured that social disability may be in fact more crippling than physical disability.
Modern social life is everywhere. Constantly in the palm of our hands. So we never have time to drop the shell. To be our real selves. Always constantly making tiny adaptations to push all the right social markers forward. Likes, followers, status, job title.
The lie of Relatability and Authenticity in Social media Content Creation
Concept 1: Impact of modern technology on social life.
Concept 2: Constant social adaptation in the digital age.
Concept 3: Challenges to authenticity in digital social spaces.
Concept 4: The paradox of relatability and authenticity in content creation on social media.
Most interestingly, digital social spaces responsible for this contortion of the self advocate that the recipe for platform success includes some sort of ‚Äúauthenticity‚Äù or ‚Äúoriginality‚Äù. But what even is that? Who are you when you not micro-adapting your social skin for relevance or survival. Have you met you?
Relatable content is touted to be the most successful type of content. ‚ÄúIf you post about how you feel, others will follow you because they feel it too‚Äù. But is this not the first crack in the glass ceiling? When you are at your most authentic, you will equally be the most relatable. Because you will be just like everybody.
Nature of the True Self/ What or who is the true self?
Concept 1: Nature of the true self and its amalgamation.
Concept 2: Cumulative experiences shaping identity.
Concept 3: Existential reflection on embracing true selves and authenticity.
Concept 4: Reflection on life as a cumulative experience, leading to existential insights.
One question that naturally flows from this inquisition into our identity is who or what is the true self. Is it the amalgamation of all these selves, or is it what remains when we strip them all away?
Life is a cumulative experience. From the moment we are born, we begin to accumulate things. Skills, ideas, things, thoughts. Our social skins are one of those things as well. They are shaped by the interaction between our unique selves and unique experiences. Man is truly realised at the moment of his death. A hodgepodge of accumulated features that we salvage along the way. We are all Frankenstein‚Äôs monsters of.
Identity and Social Context: What are these skins? How do we manage/recognise them?
Concept 1: Mechanics of social adaptation in different social environments.
Concept 2: Creation and deployment of multiple social shells.
Concept 3: Socialization as a test of survival fitness.
Concept 4: Impact of social disability on individuals in contemporary society.
The best way to improve something is to move it from the domain of reflexive automatic impulse to voluntary controlled action. By consciously creating our social skins, we know when we are creating them, what situations to best deploy them and when to take them off. We can determine the best
Existential Reflection: How do we embrace our true selves and become truly authentic
Concept 1: Consciously shaping oneself for specific circumstances.
Concept 2: Conscious creation and recognition of social skins.
Concept 3: Consciously deploying social skills in various scenarios.
Concept 4: The journey to adulthood and self-awareness.
Research questions
I act differently in different social settings.

articles/tope-arebi/Tech-Tool-Favorites-.title: Tech Tool Favorites Share Your Must-Have Tools for 1f2635c581e080ec8afced45c68bb641
articles/tope-arebi/Tech-Tool-Favorites-.content:
Tech Tool Favorites: Share Your Must-Have Tools for Productivity.

üí° Image dimensions 4:5


Tools to help you 10x your productivity
Imagine if you could somehow create more of your desired output with the same amount of time or effort. These tools are how I unlock my productivity by creating more value, in less time.
The best part is, these tools can be used for any domain, whether you‚Äôre a creator or entrepreneur
Grammarly: Elevate your written communication
I think about writing not so much as a skill, but as a core human function. It is also the bedrock of corporate communication. From sending emails, to writing newsletters, Grammarly ensures that you are being clear, precise and economical in your written communication whatever form that may be. Grammarly integrates well with your keyboard, browser, word processor and even your mobile keyboard meaning you can spell-check even your text messages.
Pocket: Build a Personal Knowledge Hub
If we live in the age of information, Pocket is your personal guide for navigating the times. I have hd an annual pocket premium subscription for the last three years and it has been invaluable for storing information. Pocket gives your bookmarked articles a home where you can read, manage them, or store them in perpetuity if you never get around to it. While there are many read-it-later apps, Pocket‚Äôs beautiful home feed and its excellent speech to audio function means you can  listen to your saved articles on-the-go just like a podcast.
Notion: Your All-in-One Workspace
If notion did not exist, this list would be a lot longer. Notion is a revolutionary notetaker that quite literally does everything. Notion is great for creating documents and notes that are easily accessible through an always present sidebar. It can create to-do-lists, kanban boards, wikis and even databases making it perfect for both personal and work-related task management.
I have tried other similar tools like Obsidian, Logseq, Coda but I always keep coming back to Notion. I‚Äôve also built some great templates throughout the year that I will sometimes share to help with planning and productivity.
Omnivore: Declutter your inbox
Omnivore is the latest tool to be added to my productivity system. Like Pocket, Omnivore acts as a capture system meaning you can save any resources to read-later. However, Omnivore does a few other things as well and it does them so well.
First of all, Omnivore is open-source, meaning I have less concerns about potential sunsetting. It is also free, so none of the features are paywalled. But what is really great about Omnivore is its ability to create email inboxes for your newsletter subscriptions. I‚Äôve been able to reduce my weekly influx of new emails by at least 80% after moving all my newsletter subscriptions to Omnivore.
Calendar: Your digital personal assistant
There is nothing more efficient that a good calendar app. The google calendar with its integration with my emails and google assistant is really like having a personal assistant. I can book meetings directly into my calendar, plan events, set deadlines all in one app. Lately, I‚Äôve been using calendar for planning by time-blocking activities throughout the week. Now I always know what I should be doing at any point in time, and when I can make up for it if something comes up to interfere with my schedule
Google Tasks: Get things done
Tasks is the simplest to-do-list app I have ever used. Many other apps seem to view the traditional box-ticking function of to-do-lists as merely one small part of the problem they need to solve. So they add tons of extra features. Tasks simply lets you create lists, and list items. And it gives you a handy little widget for your homescreen where you can mark items as done as you move through your day.
Google Workplace: Cloud storage
I‚Äôm a bit of a google fanboy so this might not apply to you, but almost all of my personally generated data that is online, is linked to google. Between google docs, sheets and drive, I can usually find a personal resource that I have created at some point in time or the other. From university notes, to work templates, essays and research papers, they all live on a google server as either a document or spreadsheet making them irreplaceable no matter what tools I may rotate in or out of my productivity system.
These tools are the backbone of my daily workflow and I literally open them everyday. Any tasks that I need to get done, no matter what area of my life that may be in goes through one of these tools and become much easier to accomplish.
What are your must-have tech tools for boosting productivity? What tools do you need to make sure that your work gets done as efficiently as possible. Share your favorites in the comments below. TechTools ProductivityHacks ProfessionalDevelopment

articles/tope-arebi/The-Case-for-Atheism.filePath: articles/tope arebi/The Case for Atheism dc70f30f095949aebc5373b20cf0022b.md
articles/tope-arebi/The-Case-for-Atheism.title: The Case for Atheism dc70f30f095949aebc5373b20cf0022b
articles/tope-arebi/The-Case-for-Atheism.content:
The Case for Atheism
First of all, I want to establish that I do not like labels. No matter how may times a word is described in a book of definitions, the meaning of a word will always be contextual. That is simply the nature of human society. Words are simply a tool for communicating, and so our interpretation of them is always inferred from the situation in which they are used. They can be purpose fit. This is why we can understand what words mean even when we have not heard them used before. But in the situation, we can understand their intent. And it does not matter what an Oxford or Longman has to say about it. They can only catch up.
The word Atheism is a label as well. And contextually, it has come to mean a person who fervently rejects the idea that there there is a God. I can understand this vehemence from previous religious adherents who, upon realising they have been conned, lash out for having been taken from a fool. However, the definition of atheism has more broad connotations than this.
Atheism is an absence of belief in the existence of deities. While the rejection of belief in deities and the belief that there are no deities are also implicit in this, they are subset of a much broader worldview. But just as we all experience life in an almost infinite number of ways, our relationship with the divine can manifest in as many ways as well.
These days, when asked what my religion is, which is often given the origin of my name, the atheist label is the only one available to me given my limited options. But my relationship with the divine is so much more than that.
Sadghuru says ‚ÄúDo not empower someone who has a limited sense of identity. That is ‚Äú

articles/tope-arebi/The-Hard-Work-of-Lov.title: The Hard Work of Love 1f2635c581e080f294cccbe266d47ec7
articles/tope-arebi/The-Hard-Work-of-Lov.content:
The Hard Work of Love
Love in the Long Term: A Commitment to the Climb
‚ÄúOh, love is real enough, you will find it some day, but it has one arch-enemy - and that is life‚Äù

Jean Anoulih

In today‚Äôs society, at least if my crude sentimental analysis of Twitter is to be trusted, love is not considered a particularly profitable venture if it is not well, profitable. And this is not necessarily exploitative. There is this misconception that in a relationship, 1 + 1 = 3 when it is really somewhere between 1 and 1.5.
TL/DR: Article Abstract
This article explores the challenges and rewards of sustaining love in the long term. It delves into the societal shifts that have impacted our perception of love, the importance of intentionality and effort in relationships, and offers practical guidance for navigating the complexities of love‚Äôs enduring journey.
The Chew
The belief that intra-specie relations must yield exponential value to be worthwhile is correlational to the rise of the concept of individual primacy among humans. For most of human existence, it has been established that man is a social creature and necessarily communal. We even have the whole ass idiom ‚Äúit takes a village‚Äù. However, with the advancement of technology and the decreasing need to rely on one another for an increasingly greater number of things, human society has become much more willing to be independent.
1. You Are a Social Animal | Psychology Today
www.psychologytoday.com
The evidence of this can be seen in the distribution of problems among countries. Developed countries face existential threats to the fabric of their society owing to issues of identity while developing countries are faced with challenges much lower on Maslow‚Äôs pyramid.
This relationship between needs and communality also surfaces in love. Passion tends to be stronger when we are young and much less fulfilled as opposed to our older years when we are striving towards more socially-oriented goals. There is simply more room at the bottom of the pyramid than at its top.
The Consequences of Shifting Priorities
Embracing the Antithesis: Love as an Investment
The modern emphasis on individual achievement and self-reliance has inadvertently created a breeding ground for fleeting connections and disposable relationships. The allure of instant gratification and the fear of vulnerability can lead us to prioritize short-term pleasure over the enduring rewards of long-term love. We may find ourselves constantly seeking the next ‚Äúbest thing,‚Äù overlooking the potential for growth and intimacy that lies in nurturing existing bonds. While the pursuit of personal goals and ambitions is undeniably important, it‚Äôs crucial to recognize that genuine love requires compromise, sacrifice, and a willingness to invest in the relationship, even when it doesn‚Äôt always yield immediate returns.
Rather than viewing love as a transaction or a means to an end, let us consider it as an investment‚Äîone that requires time, effort, and unwavering commitment. Like any worthwhile investment, love may not always yield immediate dividends, but with patience, dedication, and mutual respect, it can blossom into something truly extraordinary. The rewards of long-term love are immeasurable: deep emotional connection, unwavering support, shared experiences, and the comfort of knowing that someone has your back through thick and thin. It‚Äôs a bond that transcends the superficial and provides a sense of belonging and purpose that cannot be replicated by fleeting encounters.
1. 4 Lifelong Benefits of Long-Term Relationships | Psychology Today United Kingdom
www.psychologytoday.com
Nurturing Love‚Äôs Growth
To sustain love in the long term, we must actively nurture its growth. This involves:

Open and honest communication: Sharing thoughts, feelings, and dreams fosters intimacy and understanding.
1. Relationships and communication - Better Health Channel

www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au

Mutual respect and appreciation: Recognizing each other‚Äôs strengths, supporting each other‚Äôs goals, and expressing gratitude for each other‚Äôs presence.
Shared experiences and adventures: Creating memories together strengthens the bond and keeps the spark alive.
Forgiveness and understanding: Acknowledging that mistakes happen and choosing to forgive and move forward together.
Prioritizing quality time: Amidst busy schedules, carving out dedicated time for each other reinforces the importance of the relationship.

In today‚Äôs society, love is often viewed through a transactional lens. The prevailing narrative seems to suggest that a relationship is only valuable if it yields exponential returns, both emotionally and materially. This perspective, reflected in countless memes and Twitter threads, trivializes the profound nature of love and reduces it to a mere calculation of profit and loss. While a healthy relationship certainly brings joy, companionship, and support, it‚Äôs important to remember that love is not a guarantee of exponential returns, but rather a journey of growth and mutual support.
The idea that relationships must be endlessly profitable to be worthwhile is intrinsically linked to the rise of individualism in modern society. For centuries, humans understood the fundamental truth that we are social creatures, reliant on community for survival and well-being. The saying ‚Äúit takes a village‚Äù encapsulates this understanding, acknowledging the interconnectedness of human lives and the power of collective support. However, technological advancements and increased self-sufficiency have gradually eroded this sense of communal reliance. We now live in a world where independence is championed and self-reliance is seen as the ultimate goal.
This shift towards individualism manifests in various ways, even on a global scale. Developed countries, often characterized by high levels of individual autonomy and self-sufficiency, grapple with existential crises of identity and belonging. In contrast, developing countries, where community ties remain stronger and reliance on one another is often a necessity, face challenges that are more directly related to basic needs and survival.
This dynamic between needs and community also plays out in the realm of love. The intensity of passion often burns brightest in our younger years, when we are still striving for self-actualization and fulfillment. As we mature and our priorities shift towards more socially-oriented goals, such as building families and contributing to our communities, the nature of love evolves as well. The fiery passion of youth may give way to a deeper, more enduring love rooted in shared values and mutual respect. There‚Äôs a profound truth to the saying that there is simply more room at the bottom of Maslow‚Äôs pyramid than at its top.
The transactional view of love, coupled with the rise of individualism, has led to a culture where relationships are often seen as disposable. When the initial spark fades or challenges arise, many are quick to abandon ship, believing that love should be effortless and perpetually fulfilling. However, true love is not a fairy tale; it requires dedication, compromise, and a willingness to weather the storms of life together.
Building and maintaining a strong, lasting relationship requires intentional investment and effort. Just as a gardener tends to their plants, providing them with water, sunlight, and nutrients, so too must we nurture our relationships with care and attention. This means actively listening to our partners, expressing our love and appreciation, and working together to overcome challenges. It also means being willing to compromise, to forgive, and to grow together through life‚Äôs ups and downs.
One of the most crucial aspects of intentional investment in a relationship is open and honest communication. Sharing your thoughts, feelings, and needs with your partner creates a foundation of trust and understanding. It allows you to navigate conflicts constructively and work together to find solutions that benefit both partners. Remember, love is not about mind-reading; it‚Äôs about expressing yourself clearly and being receptive to your partner‚Äôs needs.
Another vital component of nurturing a relationship is spending quality time together. In today‚Äôs fast-paced world, it‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the hustle and bustle of daily life and neglect our relationships. However, carving out dedicated time for your partner, whether it‚Äôs a weekly date night or a quiet evening at home, strengthens your bond and fosters intimacy. It‚Äôs during these moments of shared experience and connection that love deepens and flourishes.
It‚Äôs also essential to recognize that relationships are not static; they evolve over time. As individuals grow and change, so too will their needs and desires within the relationship. Embracing this evolution and being willing to adapt and compromise is crucial for a relationship to thrive in the long run. It‚Äôs about finding new ways to connect, support each other‚Äôs dreams, and create a shared vision for the future.
While the hard work of love may seem daunting, the rewards are immeasurable. A deep and meaningful relationship provides a sense of belonging, security, and unwavering support. It enriches our lives, expands our perspectives, and challenges us to become the best versions of ourselves. Love, in its truest form, is a transformative force that empowers us to navigate life‚Äôs complexities with grace and resilience.
So, the next time you find yourself questioning the value of love or feeling discouraged by its challenges, remember that love is not a sprint but a marathon. It requires patience, perseverance, and a willingness to invest in the long-term growth of your relationship. Embrace the hard work, nurture your connection with intentionality, and you‚Äôll reap the rewards of a love that deepens and strengthens over time.
Key Takeaways:

Love is not a guarantee of exponential returns, but rather a journey of growth and mutual support.
Individualism can hinder the development of strong and lasting relationships.
Prioritize intentional investment and effort in your relationships to reap the rewards of deep connection and fulfillment.

Relevant Resource Links:

The 5 Love Languages by Gary Chapman
Attached by Amir Levine and Rachel Heller
Hold Me Tight by Sue Johnson

Conclusion: Love‚Äôs Enduring Legacy
Love in the long term is not a fairy tale; it‚Äôs a conscious choice to embark on a lifelong journey with another person. It‚Äôs a commitment to weather the storms, celebrate the triumphs, and grow together through life‚Äôs ups and downs. While it may require effort and intentionality, the rewards of a lasting love are immeasurable. So let us embrace the challenge, invest in our relationships, and create a legacy of love that transcends time and leaves an indelible mark on our lives and the lives of those we hold dear.

Post Title: New Slaves

zettelkasten/An-analysis-of-Dokkodo---21.filePath: zettelkasten/An analysis of Dokkodo - 21 principles in the path of aloneness (Miyamoto Musashi).md
zettelkasten/An-analysis-of-Dokkodo---21.title: An analysis of Dokkodo - 21 principles in the path of aloneness (Miyamoto Musashi)
zettelkasten/An-analysis-of-Dokkodo---21.content:
This is an excerpt from Miyamoto Musashi

Accept everything the way it is.
Rather than wish for a life without suffering, look for the strength to suffer well and overcome it in the end
Do not seek pleasure for its own sake.
Reject pleasures that only bring short term gratification. Suffer today, and live tomorrow as a king among men
Do not under any circumstances depend on a partial feeling.
Take your time to consider its merits with unclouded judgement, and you will make the right choice when the time comes.
Think lightly of yourself and deeply of the world.
If you only focus on yourself, you will miss the wonder and knowledge that the world has to offer
Be detached from desire your whole life long.
Rather than chase things that you don‚Äôt need, take the time to step back and enjoy something as simple as a cup of tea, or the beauty of a flower in bloom.
Do not regret what you have done
Who you are today, is not who you were yesterday, nor who you will be tomorrow. Move on and work to become better than you were before
Never be jealous
Rather than covet what others have, be grateful for the blessings you have already been given
Never let yourself be saddened by a separation
Loss is a part of life. Redirect the pain into hard work and continue fulfilling your destiny
Resentment and complaint are appropriate neither for oneself nor others.
Do not spend your whole life blaming others for failures. Take responsibility for your actions and continue working towards success.
Do not let yourself be guided by the feeling of lust or love.
When love is right you will not have to chase it. it will come to you
In all things, have no preferences
Be unbiased, open to learn from everyone and everything.
Be indifferent to where you live
It is not where you live that matters, but how you live.
Do not pursue the taste of good food.
The overindulgence of good food is beneficial for neither your mind or your body. Practice moderation in all things, especially in how you eat.
Do not hold on to possessions you o longer need
Gift your unneeded possessions to those who need it more than you do.
Do not act following customary beliefs.
Those who follow the status quo, will never change the world
Do not collect weapons or practice with weapons beyond what is useful.
Practice what works discard what doesn‚Äôt. Your time is precious, spend it wisely.
Do not fear death
Everybody dies eventually. Do not let the fear of death stop you from taking risks and achieving greatness.
Do not seek to possess either goods or fiefs for your old age.
Your possessions are of the earth and serve no purpose when you are gone. All that is left is the impact you leave behind.
Respect Buddha and the gods without counting on their help.
God has already given you all the tools you need to prevail. It is up to you to use them
You may abandon your body, but you must preserve your honour
Never sacrifice who you are and what you believe in. Stand fast in your beliefs no matter the cost.
Never stray from the way
Be unshakeable in your devotion to the set of principles under which you live your life.

zettelkasten/BDSM---Long-Distance-Activi.title: BDSM - Long Distance Activities
zettelkasten/BDSM---Long-Distance-Activi.content:
Long distance relationships are already difficult. Long distance DS relationships throw a few extra spanners in the works with the inherent need for physical presence and communication to safely and effectively navigate and explore the intense intimate experiences involved.
Principles

Connection happens in the mind and in the heart
Ensure that the mind of the submissive is grounded on the dominant. This can be done by setting specific times of the day, eg morning and night, when the submissive is set on accomplishing a task for the dominant.
You can also intersperse little activities and rituals throughout the day that will force the submissive to focus on the dominant eg
Sensory play. Involve activities that engage the senses of the submissive and remind them of the dominant‚Äôs presence

Examples

Picking out outfits

Selecting specific outfits for specific activities


Bedtime routines:

Setting bed/tuck-in times
Bedtime stories


Journaling
Position training
Gift giving

zettelkasten/Components-and-Techniques-f.filePath: zettelkasten/Components and Techniques for Improving Complete Physical Fitness.md
zettelkasten/Components-and-Techniques-f.title: Components and Techniques for Improving Complete Physical Fitness
zettelkasten/Components-and-Techniques-f.content:
Physical fitness exists in multiple dimensions

Cardiorespiratory Endurance: Definition: Cardiovascular @car

Definition: The ability of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems to deliver oxygen to muscles during sustained physical activity.
Activities to improve: Running, swimming, cycling, and aerobic exercises.


Muscular Strength:

Definition: The amount of force a muscle or muscle group can exert against a resistance in one maximal effort.
Activities to improve: Weightlifting, resistance training, and bodyweight exercises.


Muscular Endurance:

Definition: The ability of muscles to exert force repeatedly or sustain a contraction over time.
Activities to improve: High-repetition weight training, circuit training, and bodyweight exercises.


Flexibility:

Definition: The range of motion at a joint or group of joints.
Activities to improve: Stretching exercises, yoga, and Pilates.


Body Composition:

Definition: The proportion of fat, muscle, and other tissues in the body.
Activities to improve: Balanced diet, regular exercise, and strength training.


Balance:

Definition: The ability to maintain equilibrium while stationary or moving.
Activities to improve: Yoga, tai chi, and specific balance exercises.


Coordination:

Definition: The ability to integrate multiple sensory inputs with motor responses to perform tasks smoothly and accurately.
Activities to improve: Agility drills, dance, and sports-specific drills.


Agility:

Definition: The ability to change direction and position of the body quickly and efficiently.
Activities to improve: Cone drills, ladder drills, and sports-specific training.


Speed:

Definition: The ability to perform a movement or cover a distance in a short period of time.
Activities to improve: Sprinting, interval training, and plyometric exercises.

zettelkasten/Comprehensive-physical-cond.title: Comprehensive physical conditioning
zettelkasten/Comprehensive-physical-cond.content:
Idea summary:
There are a few broad goals that can be optimized for when it comes to exercise and health

Strength
Size
Endurance
Explosiveness

The method for achieving any of these 4 things varies and can be counterproductive if employed in tandem. While all of them will increase regardless of the exercises, specialised programs can increase the body‚Äôs adaptability disproportionately along any of these vectors.
To see progress in exercise volume or capacity, recovery level is a crucial factor not just in day-to-day ability, but long-term improvements.
Recovery dimensions include

muscular recovery per soreness and fiber damage and
system recovery per CO2 discard rate, grip strength and sleep quality

Another important health dimension which exercise or similar specialised training can impact is organ health, of which the

Brain,
Liverver and
Heart

as functional process machines are influenced by hormone secretion and the

Lungs and
Heart

as capacity/volume machines can be directly impacted through loading
Idea context:
Reading through Huberman lab notes while thinking about developing a comprehensive long-term workout/lifestyle plan
See Also

Andrew Huberman - Better Sleep
Andrew Huberman Muscular Adaptation

Maximising sleep quality and effects: Sunlight

zettelkasten/Concept---Repetition-streng.title: Concept - Repetition strengthens neural pathways
zettelkasten/Concept---Repetition-streng.content: Engaging in a new activity creates a new neural pathway mapping that activity to centres in the brain. This pathway is strengthened through repetition by causing repeat neuron firing along those pathways. Kind of like repeatedly driving across the same path will create deeper grooves. Repetition strengthens neural pathways in the brain leading to improved efficiency and skill acquisition making the skills more readily accessible.

zettelkasten/Concept---Vocal-Resonance-(.title: Concept - Vocal Resonance (Richness, Depth, Bodily  Source)
zettelkasten/Concept---Vocal-Resonance-(.content: Vocal resonance refers to the richness and depth perceived in a voice. It relates to how deeply rooted the voice seems within the speaker‚Äôs body (e.g., chest vs. nasal cavity) and the perceived distance or space it intends to fill or project into.

zettelkasten/Concept-Vocal-Cadence---Rhy.title: Concept Vocal Cadence - Rhythm and Pacing of Speech
zettelkasten/Concept-Vocal-Cadence---Rhy.content: Vocal cadence refers to the rhythm and pacing of speech. It‚Äôs how the flow of words is structured over time. Effective communicators (or ‚Äúseducers‚Äù in the source‚Äôs context) often create their own distinct cadence and are sensitive to the cadence of others. Rhythm can either enhance the impact of words or distract from the message.

zettelkasten/Dan-Koe---The-one-person-bu.filePath: zettelkasten/Dan Koe - The one-person business roadmap.md
zettelkasten/Dan-Koe---The-one-person-bu.title: Dan Koe - The one-person business roadmap
zettelkasten/Dan-Koe---The-one-person-bu.content:
Insights

There are 3 types of distribution: Built, borrowed and bought

There are 3 ways to distribute the content you create. To get it in the faces/hands/devices of your audience.
You can either spend the time to develop the audience a la brand building, SEO, etc.
You can ‚Äúborrow‚Äù by guest posting. You are leveraging the audience of people in your network or you reach out to.
Or pay for it through sponsored ads etc.

Mental monopoly: having great ideas that people tie to you‚Ä¶when they come across something in their life that reminds them of that idea, they will think of you

When building your distribution, your content should be geared towards tying yourself or your brand identity to great insights. Become the centre of an idea: Evangelist/knowledge centre/thought leader/cult leader. Embody an idea or principle and teach it, And when they think of a thing, they will think of you. classical conditioning

people pay for speed, aggregation and convenience

You can monetise your content by arranging and ordering it. The organisation of information is time-consuming. People will pay you for it if they believe the content being organised is useful. So you can give out your content disorganised for free
Summary
Distribution
Built distribution includes your social media following which you need to migrate off platform ASAP. Own the data. Email list gives you the most control.
Borrowed comes from features on other platforms. Guest features, article publishing, PR, retweets, etc
Bought distribution is paid ads and promotions.
Distribution Network
Growth (top): twitter, Instagram, linkedin
How you build distribution?
Authority (l): Course, cohort, community
Authenticity (r): Podcast, YouTube, Newsletter
Product that allows people invest in you and get something in return
Actionable advice, slower growth but higher customisable messaging
Brand (centre): Interests, expertise, experience
Monetization
Direct response marketing
Create a high ticket offer - drill down a market type, address a priority need
Key concepts

Distribution
Thought leadership
Monetisation of knowledge
Premiumisation

Critical Analysis
Strengths
Dan Koe does have a significant following and style that seems to work. Comments say he replicating his strategy has worked
Weaknesses
Videos give no insights as to practical things to do right now. Just a lot of anecdotes. However, this could be engineered to drive content to buy his courses
Disagreements
Agreements
I agree that the idea of niching down content for a specific audience is overrated at best and flawed at worst. Individuals are not monoliths. They have a wide range of interests. Limiting yourself to one thing means that your audience must seek out other sources to fill in the gaps. Be the centre of knowledge and you can hold attention with your brand/persona rather than individual pieces of content
Real-world applications
Develop a personal brand as a social media strategy
Connections
Other literature
Fleeting notes
Permanent notes
Structure notes

zettelkasten/Definition---Central-Nervou.title: Definition - Central Nervous System Fatigue
zettelkasten/Definition---Central-Nervou.content:
Tags: anatomy
This is a decline in the efficiency and functioning of the CNS usually due to high intensity activities requiring maximal effort like weightlifting or sprinting. CNS fatigue often results in reduced brain-muscle neural drive, decreased strength, power, coordination and reaction time. The changes are also neurochemical and can alter one‚Äôs perception of motivation, perception of effort and motor control due to its effects on serotonin, dopamine and noradrenaline.

zettelkasten/Definition---Noosphere.title: Definition - Noosphere
zettelkasten/Definition---Noosphere.content:
The noosphere is
a philosophical concept describing a global layer of human consciousness and mental activity
, seen as a potential evolutionary stage beyond the biosphere.¬†It‚Äôs essentially the realm of human thought, reason, and knowledge, influencing and interacting with the planet‚Äôs natural systems.
Elaboration:

**Origin and Development:**The term ‚Äúnoosphere‚Äù was coined by the biogeochemist Vladimir Vernadsky and further developed by the Jesuit priest and philosopher Pierre Teilhard de Chardin.¬†Vernadsky viewed it as the ‚Äúsphere of reason,‚Äù a new stage in the evolution of the planet.

Key Features:¬†Global Superorganism:¬†Some view the noosphere as a planetary superorganism, a collective consciousness of all human thought.¬†Information Processing:¬†It can be seen as a sphere of mind, where information is processed and shared through various mediums.¬†Cultural Influence:¬†The noosphere encompasses human culture, knowledge, and social relations, which can rapidly influence the environment in ways that transcend biological processes.¬†Evolutionary Stage:¬†It‚Äôs considered a stage beyond the biosphere, where humans actively shape their environment through thought and consciousness.


Key Features:
Global Superorganism:¬†Some view the noosphere as a planetary superorganism, a collective consciousness of all human thought.

Cultural Influence:¬†The noosphere encompasses human culture, knowledge, and social relations, which can rapidly influence the environment in ways that transcend biological processes.

Evolutionary Stage:¬†It‚Äôs considered a stage beyond the biosphere, where humans actively shape their environment through thought and consciousness.

Evolutionary Stage:¬†It‚Äôs considered a stage beyond the biosphere, where humans actively shape their environment through thought and consciousness.







**Examples:**The internet and technology are often cited as examples of the noosphere‚Äôs influence, as they facilitate global communication and the exchange of ideas, forming a kind of global cerebral apparatus.

**Examples:**The internet and technology are often cited as examples of the noosphere‚Äôs influence, as they facilitate global communication and the exchange of ideas, forming a kind of global cerebral apparatus.

**Relationship to Other Spheres:**The noosphere is considered to interact with and influence other spheres of the Earth, such as the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere.


Relationship to Other Spheres:
The noosphere is considered to interact with and influence other spheres of the Earth, such as the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere.


The word is derived from the Greek ŒΩœåŒøœÇ (‚Äúnous, mind, reason‚Äù) and œÉœÜŒ±·øñœÅŒ± (‚Äúsphere‚Äù), in lexical analogy to ‚Äúatmosphere‚Äù and ‚Äúbiosphere‚Äù.[5] The concept cannot be accredited to a single author. The founding authors Vernadsky and de Chardin developed two related but starkly different concepts, the former grounded in the geological sciences, and the latter in theology. Both conceptions of the noosphere share the common thesis that together human reason and scientific thought have created, and will continue to create, the next evolutionary geological layer. This geological layer is part of the evolutionary chain.[6][7] Second-generation authors, predominantly of Russian origin, have further developed the Vernadskian concept, creating the related concepts: noocenosis and noocenology.[

Under US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) labeling regulations, a food product is permitted to be labeled as ‚Äúsugar-free‚Äù if it contains less than 0.5 grams of sugars per its defined Reference Amount Customarily Consumed (RACC), or per labeled serving size if the RACC is small. zettelkasten/Framework---OODA-loop-(Deci.title: Framework - OODA loop (Decision Making Framework )
zettelkasten/Framework---OODA-loop-(Deci.content:
Tags: decision-making
Related Notes: Key Concepts Problem Solving (Key%20Concepts%20Problem%20Solving%201f3635c581e08057a33fe60595c33010.md)
The OODA loop is a decision-making framework primarily used for making strategy decisions and responding effectively to situational changes. Developed by United States Air Force Colonel John Boyd, it emphasizes that the speed at which one can cycle through the process (Observe, Orient, Decide, Act) is critical. The core idea is that by completing OODA loops faster than an opponent or by reacting more quickly to a changing environment, one can gain a significant advantage, often by disrupting the adversary‚Äôs plans and decision-making processes.
Source

tag1

zettelkasten/Framework---PACE-(Communica.title: Framework - PACE (Communication Methodology)
zettelkasten/Framework---PACE-(Communica.content:
Related Notes: Key Concepts Problem Solving (Key%20Concepts%20Problem%20Solving%201f3635c581e08057a33fe60595c33010.md)
Primary, alternate, contingency and emergency¬†(PACE) is a methodology for building communication plans. The methodology provisions that after stakeholders for a piece of communication are identified, one must determine the best four separate, different, independent and redundant communication channels for each of the identified parties. The order of PACE also determines priority meaning that communication moves through each channel sequentially until communication ca be established.
Source
